CHAPTER 2: HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION
Section
   
2-2-1   Commission Established; Membership
   
2-2-2   Terms of Office
   
2-2-3   Compensation
   
2-2-4   Meetings
   
2-2-5   Officers
   
2-2-6   Powers and Duties
§ 2-2-1 COMMISSION ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   Commission Established. There is hereby established and entitled the
historic preservation commission for the city.
   (B)   Membership. The historic preservation commission of the city shall
consist of five (5) persons, to be appointed by the mayor with the approval of
the City Council. The commission shall consist of one member of the planning
commission, one member of the City Council, two (2) members of the Lincoln
County historical society or other comparable organization, and one member at
large.
   (C)   Residency. Commissioners shall be residents of the city.
§ 2-2-2 TERMS OF OFFICE.
   (A)   Staggered Terms. The terms of office of the members of the historic
preservation commission shall be as follows:
      (1)   One commissioner shall be appointed for a term of one year;
      (2)   Two (2) commissioners shall be appointed for a term of two (2)
years; and
      (3)   Two (2) commissioners shall be appointed for a term of three (3)
years.
   (B)   Term Established. At the expiration of the terms of office of the
commissioners appointed for one year terms and two (2) year terms, thereafter,
each commissioner appointed to succeed them shall be appointed for a term of
three (3) years and until his successor in office has been appointed and
qualifies. The terms of the commissioners shall begin on May 1.
   (C)   Filling Vacancy. Any vacancy which may occur through death,
resignation, or otherwise shall be filled for the unexpired term in the manner
hereinabove provided.
§ 2-2-3 COMPENSATION.
   No compensation for the services of the commission shall be allowed to any
member thereof.
§ 2-2-4 MEETINGS.
   The commission shall determine the time of its regular meetings, and special
meetings of the commission may be called by the chairman or by a majority of
the commissioners.
§ 2-2-5 OFFICERS.
   The commissioners shall, when so appointed, elect one of their number
chairman, another vice chairman, and another secretary. Thereafter, officers
shall be chosen at the first meeting in the month of May of each year or as
soon thereafter as practicable.
§ 2-2-6 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The commissioners shall act in an advisory capacity to the mayor, City
Council, and city manager in connection with the care, management, and
preservation of an historic district or districts which shall be hereafter
created. The commission shall advise with and suggest to the mayor, council,
and city manager the area or areas to be designated for historic preservation
and methods of improving and regulating such district including, but not
limited to, suggesting and altering from time to time necessary rules and
regulations for such established district or districts; provided however, that
no such rules and regulations shall be of any effect unless first approved by
the council.
CHAPTER 3: EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY
Section
   
2-3-1   Purpose
   
2-3-2   Department of Emergency Management
   
2-3-3   Director of Emergency Management
   
2-3-4   Emergency Powers
   
2-3-5   Enforcement of Laws and Ordinances
   
2-3-6   Compensation; City Responsibility for Injuries
§ 2-3-1 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to create an emergency management agency for
the city to be prepared for, and to function in the event of, emergencies
endangering the lives and property of the people of the city. The duty of such
emergency management agency shall be the protection of the lives and health of
the citizens of the city and of property rights, both private and public, and
to perform all functions necessary and incident thereto.
§ 2-3-2 DEPARTMENT OF EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT.
   There is hereby established under the executive branch of the government of
the city a department of emergency management, which shall consist of:
   (A)   A director of emergency management who shall be appointed by the city
manager, and when necessary for the good of the service, suspended, demoted, or
removed by the city manager.
   (B)   An emergency management advisory committee. This committee shall
consist of the mayor as chairman and five (5) members appointed by the mayor
and serving at his pleasure. The committee shall select from its members a vice
chairman and secretary. It shall hold such meetings as are directed by the
mayor or the director of emergency management.
(Ord. 2015-10, passed 12-8-2015)
§ 2-3-3 DIRECTOR OF EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT.
   (A)   Department Head; Responsibilities. The director of emergency
management shall be the executive head of the department of emergency
management, and shall be responsible for carrying out the emergency management
program of the city.
   (B)   Compensation. For fiscal year 2015-2016, the director shall receive
such compensation as was budgeted for the position by the City Council.
Commencing with fiscal year 2016-2017 and each fiscal year thereafter, such
compensation shall be as approved and budgeted by the City Council.
   (C)   Powers and Duties.
      (1)   It is the duty of the director of emergency management, as soon as
practicable after his appointment, to perfect an agency to carry out the
purposes set forth in this chapter.
      (2)   The director shall have all necessary power and authority to form
committees or other bodies and to appoint and designate the chairman or chief
officer of such bodies as may be necessary to perfect such an agency.
      (3)   The director shall have such further duty and responsibility to
cooperate with all emergency management agencies of other governmental units,
including the state and federal government.
      (4)   The director shall be an officer of the city and shall have the
power necessary to enforce the duties provided in the chapter.
   (D)   Formulate Plans; Gather Information. The director of emergency
management is further authorized to formulate written plans and gather
information and keep written records thereof to govern the functions of the
emergency management agency. He may carry out plans with the state officials of
emergency management in cooperating with the federal government and to make
available to the city and county program the benefits of Pub. Law No. 85-606,
subject to the approval of the City Council, the county, and emergency
management committee.
(Ord. 2015-10, passed 12-8-2015)
§ 2-3-4 EMERGENCY POWERS.
   In the event of an enemy caused emergency or emergency resulting from
natural causes, the director of emergency management, after due authorization
from the City Council, shall have the power and authority to enforce all rules
and regulations relating to emergency management and, if necessary, take
control of transportation, communications, stocks of fuel, food, clothing,
medicine, and public utilities for the purpose of protecting the civilian
population. He shall cooperate in every way with the activities of other
governmental agencies or emergency management agencies. If required by the
mayor, he shall have control over any and all funds allocated from any source
for the purpose of alleviating distress conditions in the city.
§ 2-3-5 ENFORCEMENT OF LAWS AND ORDINANCES.
   The director of emergency management and other members of the emergency
management agency created by him shall have the power and authority to enforce
the laws of the state and ordinances of the city during the period of
emergency, and shall at such time have the further power to make arrests for
violations of such laws or ordinances.
§ 2-3-6 COMPENSATION; CITY RESPONSIBILITY FOR INJURIES.
   All members of the emergency management agency created hereunder shall serve
without compensation. The city shall be responsible as required by law for any
personal injury received by any member of such agency while acting in the line
of duty.
CHAPTER 4: PARK COMMISSION
Section
   
2-4-1   Commission Established; Membership; Meetings
   
2-4-2   Terms of Office
   
2-4-3   Officers
   
2-4-4   Powers and Duties
   
2-4-5   Park Property Defined
   
2-4-6   Conflict of Interest
   
2-4-7   Acceptance of Gifts
§ 2-4-1 COMMISSION ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP; MEETINGS.
   (A)   Commission Established; Appointment. There is hereby established a
park commission for the city. This organization shall be called “board of park
commissioners” of the city. Said board shall consist of five (5) persons, to be
appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the City Council.
   (B)   Residency. A park board member need not be a resident of the city.
   (C)   Compensation. No compensation for services of the commission shall be
allowed to any member thereof.
   (D)   Meetings.
      (1)   The board shall determine the time of its regular meetings.
      (2)   Special meetings of the park commission may be called by the
chairman or a majority of the commissioners.
§ 2-4-2 TERMS OF OFFICE.
   (A)   Staggered Terms. The terms of office of the members of the board of
park commissioners of the city shall be as follows: one commissioner shall be
appointed for a term of one year; two (2) commissioners for a term of two (2)
years; and two (2) commissioners for a term of three (3) years.
   (B)   Term Established. At the expiration of the terms of office of the
first commissioners appointed hereunder, each park commissioner shall be
appointed for a term of three (3) years and until his successor in office has
been appointed and qualifies. The terms of the commissioners shall begin on
May 1.
   (C)   Filling Vacancies. Any vacancy which may occur through death,
resignation, or otherwise, may be filled for the unexpired term in like manner.
(Ord. 1996-03, passed 4-9-1996)
§ 2-4-3 OFFICERS.
   The board shall, when so appointed, elect one of its number chairman of the
board and another vice chairman, and the board shall elect a member secretary,
and thereafter such officers shall be chosen on the first Monday of May in each
year, or as soon thereafter as practicable.
§ 2-4-4 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   Generally. The board of park commissioners shall act in an advisory
capacity to the mayor and City Council and the city manager in connection with
the care, management and control of all parks and grounds used for park
purposes, all boulevards and parkways, now or hereafter owned by or under the
control of the city. The board shall advise with, and suggest to, the mayor and
council and the city manager, methods of improving and adorning parks,
boulevards and parkways.
   (B)   Rules and Regulations. The board shall have power to make and alter,
from time to time, necessary rules and regulations for the maintenance of
order, safety, and decency in the parks, both within and without the limits of
the city; provided, that no such rules or regulations shall be of any effect
unless they shall have been first approved by the City Council.
   (C)   Police Jurisdiction. For the purpose of enforcing such rules and
regulations, all such parks and property within or without the limits of the
city are hereby placed under the police jurisdiction of the city. Any member of
the police department may arrest, without warrant, in any such parks or places,
whether within or without the limits of the city, any person who has broken any
park rule or committed any violation of such rules or the ordinances of the
city in the park, and the municipal court of the city shall have jurisdiction
of all such violations committed within the limits of the parks.
§ 2-4-5 PARK PROPERTY DEFINED.
   The term PARK PROPERTY includes all parks, street parkings, and all
buildings, structures, improvements, seats, benches, foundations, boats,
floats, walks, drives, roads, trees, plants, herbages, flowers, and other
things thereon, and the enclosures of the same, and all trees on streets or
thoroughfares, resting places, water stations, playgrounds, or the like, and
all boulevards, parkways, roads, or drives between parks.
§ 2-4-6 CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
   No member of the board of park commissioners shall be concerned in any
contract with the city or any of its departments, either as contractor,
subcontractor, bondsman, or other party directly or indirectly interested.
§ 2-4-7 ACCEPTANCE OF GIFTS.
   (A)   Conveyance to City. Real or personal property may be granted,
bequeathed, devised, or conveyed to the city for the purpose of the improvement
or ornamentation of such parks or approaches, or for the establishment or
maintenance therein of museums, zoological or other gardens, collections of
natural history, observatories, monuments, statues, fountains, or other works
of art, upon such trusts and conditions as may be prescribed by the grantors or
devisors thereof, and accepted by the City Council.
   (B)   City Management and Control. All property so devised, granted,
bequeathed, or conveyed, and the rents, issues, profits, and income thereof
shall be subject to the exclusive management, direction, and control of the
city.
CHAPTER 5: GOLF COURSE ADVISORY BOARD
Section
   
2-5-1   Board Established; Membership
   
2-5-2   Terms of Office
   
2-5-3   Compensation
   
2-5-4   Meetings
   
2-5-5   Officers
   
2-5-6   Powers and Duties
§ 2-5-1 BOARD ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   Board Established. There is hereby established and entitled the
Chandler golf course advisory board.
   (B)   Membership. The Chandler golf course advisory board shall consist of
five (5) persons to be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the City
Council.
   (C)   Qualifications. Members shall meet at least two (2) of the following
requirements:
      (1)   Resident of the city of Chandler;
      (2)   Own or be employed by a business in the city limits of Chandler;
      (3)   Annual member of the Chandler golf course.
(Ord. 2005-04, passed 8-1-2005)
§ 2-5-2 TERMS OF OFFICE.
   (A)   Appointment. The Chandler golf course advisory board members will be
appointed for twenty-four (24) months. At the conclusion of the twenty-four
(24) month period, the City Council will determine if the board should be
reappointed for additional service.
   (B)   Cause for Removal. Should any member miss three (3) consecutive
regular meetings of the Chandler golf course advisory board, the remaining
members shall immediately report such fact to the City Council, at which time
the City Council may remove said member at its discretion. Violation of the
city of Chandler’s conflict of interest policy shall be cause for immediate
removal from office.
   (C)   Filling Vacancy. Any vacancy which may occur through death,
resignation, removal, or otherwise shall be filled for the unexpired term in
the manner hereinabove provided.
(Ord. 2005-04, passed 8-1-2005)
§ 2-5-3 COMPENSATION.
   No compensation for the services of the Chandler golf course advisory board
shall be allowed to any member.
(Ord. 2005-04, passed 8-1-2005)
§ 2-5-4 MEETINGS.
   The Chandler golf course advisory board shall meet on call at the direction
of the chairman of the board, the city manager, or the council. Such meetings
will be in compliance with the state open meeting laws.
(Ord. 2005-04, passed 8-1-2005)
§ 2-5-5 OFFICERS.
   The board members shall, when so appointed, elect one of their number
chairman, another vice chairman, and another secretary. Then, at the first
board meeting in the month of July of each year or as soon thereafter as
practicable.
(Ord. 2005-04, passed 8-1-2005)
§ 2-5-6 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Chandler golf course advisory board shall act only in an advisory
capacity to the mayor, City Council, city manager and the superintendent of the
Chandler city golf course. Said board will have no responsibilities for the
supervision, promotion, demotion, or dismissal of any golf course employees or
golf course vendors. The board will develop recommendations and planning on the
expansion of the course, funding for the expansion, new services at the course,
and the addition of any new facilities and equipment consistent with the
community needs.
(Ord. 2005-04, passed 8-1-2005)

§ 3-1-1 DEPOSITORIES DESIGNATED; FUNDS DEPOSITED.
   (A)   Deposit of Funds. Funds of the city shall be deposited as required by
law.
   (B)   Depositories. All banks and all savings and loan associations within
this state which are incorporated under federal or state law are hereby
designated as depositories for the funds of the city.
   (C)   Daily Deposits; Transfer of Funds.
      (1)   The city treasurer shall deposit daily all public funds received by
him in such banks or savings and loan associations.
      (2)   Funds may be transferred from one depository to another as the City
Council may direct by motion or resolution.
§ 3-1-2 CONTRACTUAL SERVICES DEFINED FOR PURCHASING.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definition shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CONTRACTUAL SERVICES. Services performed for the city by persons not in the
employment of the city, and may include the use of equipment or the furnishing
of commodities in connection with the services under express or implied
contract. CONTRACTUAL SERVICES shall include: travel; freight; express; parcel
post; postage; telephone; telegraph; utilities; rents; printing out; binding;
repairs, alterations and maintenance of buildings, equipment, streets and
bridges, and other physical facilities of the city; and other services
performed for the city by persons not in the employment of the city.
§ 3-1-3 PURCHASES OF GOODS, SERVICES AND CAPITAL.
   (A)   The City Manager shall designate certain individuals as purchasing
officers empowered to purchase or contract against budget appropriations. Only
these designated individuals will be empowered to obligate the city.
   (B)   For all purchases of goods, services or capital (all purchases or
disbursements other than payroll and debt service) for which the obligation and
final invoice for the payment of the obligation does not occur within the same
month, purchase orders or contracts shall be prepared and approved, in writing,
by a designated purchasing officer prior to the time the purchase commitment is
made. The approved purchase order or contract shall be forwarded to an officer
or employee charged with keeping the appropriation and expenditure records
(encumbering clerk) who shall determine that unencumbered appropriations exist
for that purpose. Upon such determination, the encumbering clerk shall attest
to that fact in writing. If appropriation is not available for the proposed
purchase or commitment, the purchase or commitment shall not proceed until
budget amendments are authorized to provide sufficient appropriation.
      Upon approval of the purchasing officer and encumbering clerk, an
encumbrance shall be recorded in the appropriation and expenditure records in
the amount or estimated amount of the commitment.
      These encumbering requirements shall not apply to the following type of
purchases or commitments:
      (1)   Payroll and payroll related expenses.
      (2)   Utility and telephone services by entities governed by state
corporation commission.
      (3)   Insurance contracts.
      (4)   Purchases where the obligation and final invoice are processed in
the same month.
   (C)   For all purchases or contracts for goods, services, or capital over
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000), City Council approval shall be obtained prior
to the time the commitment is made, and such approval shall be recorded in the
minutes of the council.
   (D)   After satisfactory delivery of the merchandise or completion of
contract provisions, an invoice or claim form shall be obtained adequately
documenting request for payment. The officer or employee receiving satisfactory
delivery of merchandise or contract service shall acknowledge such fact by
signing the invoice, claim form, delivery ticket, receiving advice or purchase
order form.
      The invoice or claim form, along with the written acknowledgment of
receipt, shall be forwarded to the officer or employee responsible for
processing accounts payable who shall review the invoice for accuracy and
propriety, including comparison to the authorized purchase order or contract,
if applicable.
      Upon completion of the accounts payable officer review, the invoices or
purchase orders along with the related supporting documentation shall be
submitted to the City Manager for consideration and approval of payment, along
with an accompanying invoice or claims listing, which shall be approved in
writing by the City Manager. An invoice approval report or claims listing will
be presented to the City Council at the next regular council meeting.
   (E)   Upon approval of the invoices, claims or purchase orders for payment
by the City Manager, checks or other payment documents as authorized by state
law shall be prepared and submitted to the city treasurer, along with a copy of
the approved invoice or claims listing.
      The treasurer shall compare the checks or other payment documents to the
invoice or claims listing and verify their accuracy. Upon verification, the
treasurer and the city clerk shall sign the checks or other documents and
prepare them for distribution. In addition, the treasurer shall prepare or
cause to be prepared a check or disbursement register.
   (F)   The city treasurer shall record or cause to be recorded in the
appropriate journals and ledgers the purchases and cash disbursements incurred
and paid within the same month.
(Ord. 2008-03, passed 5-13-2008; Ord. 2023-01, passed 5-9-2023)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. § 17-102
§ 3-1-4 COUNCIL APPROVAL FOR CERTAIN CONTRACTS OR PURCHASES.
   See subsection
3-1-3(C) of this chapter for purchases over twenty-five thousand dollars
($25,000.00).
(Ord. 2008-03, passed 5-13-2008)
§ 3-1-5 COMPETITIVE BIDDING.
   (A)   The city shall adhere to the provisions of 61 O.S. §§ 101 et seq.,
when determining when competitive bidding is required and the manner in which
competitive bids will be obtained.
   (B)   In addition to the requirements of subsection (A) of this section,
public trusts created pursuant to 60 O.S. § 176, of which the city is
beneficiary, shall also follow the competitive bidding provisions of 60 O.S. §
176(G).
(Ord. 2008-03, passed 5-13-2008)
Charter reference:
   Purchases and sales, see §
4.3
§ 3-1-6 PURCHASES EXCLUDED FROM BIDDING PROCESS.
   The following may be purchased without giving an opportunity for competitive
bidding:
   (A)   Supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services whose cost does
not exceed twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) in a single transaction;
   (B)   Supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services which can be
furnished only by a single dealer, or which have a uniform price wherever
bought;
   (C)   Supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services purchased from
another unit of government at a price deemed below that obtainable from private
dealers, including government surplus;
   (D)   Equipment to replace existing equipment which has become inoperable
when the council declares the purchase an emergency;
   (E)   Contractual services, including, but not limited to, natural gas,
electricity, telephone service, purchased from a public utility at a price or
rate determined by the state corporation commission or other governmental
authority;
   (F)   Supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services when purchased
at a price not exceeding a price set therefor by the state purchasing agency or
any other state agency hereafter authorized to regulate prices for things
purchased by the state, whether such price is determined by a contract
negotiated with a vendor or otherwise; and
   (G)   Contractual services of a professional nature, such as engineering,
architectural and medical services unless competitive bidding is required by
applicable law or regulation.
(Ord. 1993-01, passed 2-2-1993; Ord. 2002-01, passed 2-5-2002)
Charter reference:
   Purchases and sales, see §
4.3
§ 3-1-7 SALE OF SURPLUS MATERIALS; COMPETITIVE BIDDING.
   No surplus or obsolete supplies, materials or equipment may be sold until
the City Council shall have declared them obsolete or surplus. The council may
authorize the sale of any obsolete or surplus supplies, materials, or equipment
either by sealed bids or by public auction. When the sealed bid procedure is
used, the City Manager, except as otherwise provided below, shall advertise
them for sale in a newspaper of general circulation in the city or give notice
in such other manner as he deems necessary adequately to reach prospective
buyers to give them opportunity to make necessary bids. All bids shall be
sealed and shall be opened in public at a designated time and place, except
when the sale is by auction. The City Manager may repeatedly reject all bids
and advertise or give notice again. He shall sell such supplies, materials or
equipment to the highest responsible bidder. In case of a tie, if necessary, he
shall cast lots to determine to whom to sell, or he may divide the sale among
two (2) or more tying, always selling to the highest responsible bidder or
bidders.
§ 3-1-8 CITY SALES AND PURCHASES RESTRICTED.
   (A)   Selling by Council. No member of the City Council may sell, or furnish
for a consideration, any materials or supplies for use of the city; and any
member of the council voting for, or consenting to, or being a party to, such
contract or purchase is personally liable as provided by Oklahoma law.
   (B)   Contracts with Council. The City Council shall not make any contract
with any of its members, or in which any of its members shall be directly or
indirectly interested, such contracts being prohibited by law.
   (C)   City Officers; Conflict of Interest; Contracts. No officer of the city
may become directly or indirectly interested individually in any sale, lease,
or contract which he is authorized to make, such being prohibited by law.
§ 3-1-9 BUDGET AND APPROPRIATIONS.
   (A)   Budget Preparation. The City Council shall meet on a date that is
agreeable to the majority of the council members to develop a budget, including
the estimated needs and probable income, for the next fiscal year, in the
manner required by law.
   (B)   Appropriations. Appropriations for the city shall be made as provided
by law.
   (C)   Transfers. Unencumbered appropriations balances of items of less
immediately urgent need, or any part thereof, may be transferred to other items
of appropriation to meet more immediately urgent needs in the manner provided
by law.
§ 3-1-10 FUNDS; WARRANTS; BONDS.
   (A)   Funding and Accounting Generally. The revenues and other resources of
the city shall be divided into funds as provided by law and accounted for as
provided thereby.
   (B)   Sinking Fund.
      (1)   It is the duty of the officers of the city to handle, deposit,
invest, and use the money in the sinking fund of the city in the manner
provided by law.
      (2)   The city treasurer shall deposit daily all uninvested sinking fund
money in his hands in banks as provided by law.
   (C)   Claims and Invoices. Claims and invoices against the city shall be
made and processed as provided by law.
   (D)   Warrants; Disbursement of Funds. Warrants shall be issued and
processed, and funds of the city disbursed, only for legal purposes and in
accordance with law.
   (E)   Bonds, Issuance and Sale. Bonds of the city shall be issued, sold,
paid, and handled in all respects as provided by law.
§ 3-1-11 EXAMINATION AND AUDIT OF BOOKS AND RECORDS.
   (A)   Books Open to Council Inspection. The books of the city treasurer
shall be subject to examination by the City Council at all times, as provided
by law. Likewise, the records of the city clerk and of all other officers and
employees of the city shall be subject to inspection by the City Council at all
times.
   (B)   Annual Audit by Public Accountant. The City Council shall designate a
qualified public accountant to audit the financial records and transactions of
the city treasurer, the city clerk, and all other personnel of the city who
keep financial records and make financial transactions, as of the end of every
fiscal year, at least; the accountant shall make such audit and shall report to
the City Council.
   (C)   Petition for State Audit. Upon petition of a number of voters of the
city equal at least to twenty-five percent (25%) of the number of people voting
at the last general city election for the city office receiving the highest
number of votes, the financial books and records of the city will be audited by
the state auditor and inspector as provided by law.
§ 3-1-12 INSURANCE FOR PROPERTY, VEHICLES.
   (A)   Property. The City Council may insure property of the city as
authorized by law. Any money received as a result of destruction, damages, or
loss of such insured property shall be accounted for and used as provided by
law.
   (B)   Negligent Operation of Vehicle. The City Council may purchase
insurance to pay damage to persons sustaining injuries or damages to property
as a result of negligent operation of vehicles, motorized equipment of the
city, or any acts of the city as authorized by law.
§ 3-1-13 DEBT SERVICE.
   (A)   All long term indebtedness, in the form of bonds, notes or lease
purchase obligations, shall only be incurred in the manner provided by law.
   (B)   Once lawfully incurred, payments of principal and interest on the
bonds or notes and payments on the lease purchase obligations shall be paid in
accordance with the terms as specified in the bond indenture, note agreement or
lease purchase contract by the city treasurer without further approval of the
governing body.
   (C)   The manner of payment shall be consistent with the manner used for the
payment of purchases of goods, services or capital as described in subsection
3-1-3(E) of this chapter.
   (D)   The city treasurer shall record or cause to be recorded in the
appropriate journals and ledgers the debt service payments and maintain current
records of the remaining amount of indebtedness.
(Ord. 2008-03, passed 5-13-2008)
§ 3-1-14 INTERFUND TRANSFERS.
   (A)   All transfers of resources between funds shall only be made in
accordance with the appropriations provided by the City Council for such
transfers. Such appropriations shall be contained in the original or amended
budget of the city.
   (B)   Once lawfully appropriated, interfund transfer payments may be made by
the city treasurer without further City Council approval. Such transfers,
however, may not exceed the amount lawfully appropriated.
   (C)   The manner of payment of these interfund transfers shall be consistent
with the manner used for the payment of purchases of goods, services and
capital as described in subsection
3-1-3(E) of this chapter.
   (D)   The city treasurer shall record or cause to be recorded these
interfund transfers in the appropriate journals and ledgers.
(Ord. 2008-03, passed 5-13-2008)
§ 3-1-15 PETTY CASH.
   (A)   As provided for in 11 O.S. § 17-102(D), the city may have petty cash
accounts for use in making certain small payments for costs incurred in
operating the municipality.
   (B)   Each petty cash account established shall require City Council
approval, including the amount of the petty cash imprest balance. However, in
no case, should the imprest balance exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   (C)   The petty cash accounts shall be reimbursed by utilizing properly
itemized invoices or petty cash voucher slips and by then processing the
reimbursement in the manner used for payment of purchases of goods, services
and capital.
(Ord. 2008-03, passed 5-13-2008)
§ 3-1-16 INCURRING INDEBTEDNESS.
   As provided for in article 10, section 26 of the Oklahoma constitution, the
city is prohibited from becoming indebted in any manner for any purpose in an
amount exceeding the amount appropriated by the City Council for such purpose,
without voter approval.
(Ord. 2008-03, passed 5-13-2008)
§ 3-1-17 FINANCIAL REPORTING.
   The finance director, or their designee, shall prepare a monthly budget
status report comparing the actual results to date with the budget
appropriations. The report shall be placed on the agenda for City Council
acknowledgment at the next regular City Council meeting following month end.
(Ord. 2008-03, passed 5-13-2008)
§ 3-1-18 APPLICABILITY TO PUBLIC TRUSTS.
   (A)   For all public trusts created pursuant to 60 O.S. §§ 176 through 180,
for which the city is beneficiary and for which the trust’s governing body
(trustees) are comprised entirely of members of the City Council, the
requirements of this chapter, excluding section 3-1-16, “Incurring
Indebtedness”, of this chapter, shall apply.
   (B)   For the purposes of the public trusts, as used above, the terms
GOVERNING BODY shall mean board of trustees of the trust, CHIEF EXECUTIVE
OFFICER shall mean trust manager as appointed by the trustees, CITY TREASURER
shall mean trust treasurer as appointed by the trustees or required by the
trust indenture.
(Ord. 2008-03, passed 5-13-2008)

§ 3-2-1 SCOPE.
   This chapter shall apply to the contracting by the city for any public
improvement, or the construction or repair of any public building, where the
value of the contract exceeds twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). No
contract involving sums in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00)
shall be split into partial contracts involving sums below twenty-five thousand
dollars ($25,000.00) for the purpose of avoiding the requirements of this
chapter. All such partial contracts shall be void.
(Ord. 2002-01, passed 2-5-2002)
§ 3-2-2 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BIDDING DOCUMENTS. The bid notice, plans and specifications, bidding form,
bidding instructions, special provisions and all other written instruments
prepared by or on behalf of the city for use by prospective bidders on a public
construction contract.
   PUBLIC CONSTRUCTION CONTRACT or CONTRACT. Any contract, exceeding twenty-
five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) in amount, awarded by the city for the
purpose of making any public improvements or constructing any public building
or making repairs to the same.
   PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT. Any beneficial or valuable change or addition,
betterment, enhancement or amelioration of or upon any real property, or
interest therein, belonging to the city intended to enhance its value, beauty
or utility or to adapt it to new or further purposes. The term does not include
the direct purchase of materials, equipment or supplies by the city.
   RETAINAGE. The difference between the amount earned by the contractor on a
public construction contract, with the work being accepted by the city, and the
amount paid on the contract by the city.
(Ord. 2002-01, passed 2-5-2002)
§ 3-2-3 BIDDING; ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Bidding Requirement. See section
3-1-5  of this title regarding competitive bidding.
   (B)   Contract, Bonds, Insurance.
      (1)   No work shall be commenced until a written contract is executed and
all required bonds and insurance have been provided by the contractor to the
city.
      (2)   All insurance or bonds shall be secured from an insurance or
indemnity carrier licensed to do business in the state.
(Ord. 2008-03, passed 5-13-2008)
§ 3-2-4 NONRESIDENT BIDDERS; RESIDENT PREFERENCE.
   (A)   Nonresidents. The city shall not contract with a bidder who is not a
resident of this state unless:
      (1)   No bids are submitted by a resident bidder;
      (2)   The bid submitted by the nonresident bidder is more than five
percent (5%) less than the bid submitted by any resident bidder;
      (3)   The bid submitted by a nonresident bidder, who resides in a state
which has a reciprocal agreement with this state regarding nonresident bidding
requirements, is less than the bid submitted by any resident bidder by that
percentage which is at least equal to that required by the reciprocal state of
a bidder from this state. States not having such reciprocal agreements shall
comply with provisions of subsection (A)(2) of this section.
   (B)   Residents.
      (1)   A RESIDENT BIDDER is any person, firm, corporation or other legal
entity, if at the time the contract is advertised for bids and at the time bids
are submitted, it meets the following requirements:
         (a)   Maintains its principal place of business in the state of
Oklahoma.
         (b)   If the bidder is a corporation, then it must be domiciled or
incorporated in Oklahoma and a majority of its outstanding shares must be owned
by one or more individual citizens and residents of the state of Oklahoma who
pay income, real property and personal property taxes in this state.
         (c)   If the bidder is a partnership, general or limited, or other
legal entity, then the partners or associates owning a majority beneficial
interest therein must be citizens and residents of the state of Oklahoma who
pay income, real property and personal property taxes in this state. If one or
more partners or associates are corporations, then a majority of its
outstanding shares must be owned by individual citizens and residents of the
state of Oklahoma who pay income, real property and personal property taxes in
this state. If the entity is a trust, then a majority of the beneficial
interest thereof must be owned by individual citizens and residents of the
state of Oklahoma.
         (d)   If the bidder is an individual, then the individual must be a
citizen and resident of the state of Oklahoma who pays income, real property
and personal property taxes in the state of Oklahoma.
      (2)   The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to any
contract in which federal funds are involved.
      (3)   A resident bidder shall submit with his bid an affidavit stating
that he meets the qualifications of this subsection (B).
§ 3-2-5 PURCHASING AGENTS AUTHORIZED.
   The City Council may duly appoint as its agent any individual or individual
of a legal entity, with whom the city has duly entered into a public contract
pursuant to law, to make purchases necessary for carrying out the public
contract.
§ 3-2-6 PROPOSALS, NOTICE.
   All proposals to award public construction contracts shall be made equally
and uniformly known by the city to all prospective bidders and the public in
the following manner:
   (A)   Mail. Notice thereof shall be mailed, by first class mail, to all
known prospective bidders who have made known, in writing, to the public agency
their interest in bidding within the twelve (12) months immediately preceding
the date of opening bids, at least twenty (20) days prior to the time set for
opening bids.
   (B)   Newspaper. Notice thereof shall be given by publication in a newspaper
of general circulation and published in the county where the work, or the major
part of it, is to be done, such notice by publication to be published in two
(2) consecutive weekly issues of the newspaper, with the first publication
thereof to be at least twenty (20) days prior to the date set for opening bids.
   (C)   Trade or Construction Publications. Notice thereof shall be sent to
trade or construction publications for their use and information whenever the
estimated cost of the contract exceeds fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00);
provided however, that this section shall not be construed as requiring the
publication of the notice in such trade or construction publication.
§ 3-2-7 BID NOTICE CONTENTS.
   All bid notices shall set forth the following information:
   (A)   The character of the proposed public construction contract in
sufficient detail that all bidders shall know exactly what their obligation
will be, either in the bid notice itself or by reference to bidding documents
on file in the main office of the city;
   (B)   The name of the officer, agent or employee of the city, and the office
location and address of such person, from whom a complete set of bidding
documents regarding such proposed contract may be obtained, together with the
amount of the cost deposit required therefor, if any;
   (C)   The date, time and place of opening of the sealed bids;
   (D)   The name and office location and address of the office of the city to
whom the sealed bids should be submitted;
   (E)   The period of time not to exceed sixty (60) days after the opening of
the bids, within which the contract will be executed; and
   (F)   Any additional information regarding such proposed contract deemed by
the city to be of beneficial interest to prospective bidders or the public.
§ 3-2-8 BID DOCUMENTS ON FILE; AVAILABLE TO PROSPECTIVE BIDDERS.
   At least one complete set of bidding documents regarding a proposed public
construction contract shall be on file in the main office of the city at least
twenty (20) days prior to the date set for opening bids. The officer, agent or
employee of the city designated in the bid notice shall have a sufficient
number of complete sets of the bidding documents and shall provide a complete
set of same to any prospective bidder, upon request; provided however, that the
city may require a reasonable deposit for each such set; provided, that such
deposit shall not exceed the actual cost of duplicating or printing. The city
may retain all or part of the deposit if so stated in the notice for bids.
§ 3-2-9 PREQUALIFICATION OF BIDDERS.
   In order to determine the financial responsibility of bidders, the city may
require prospective bidders to prequalify as responsible bidders prior to
submitting bids on a public construction contract. Notice of any such
prequalification requirement shall be made equally and uniformly known to the
contractors and the public in the same manner as proposals to award public
construction contracts, as set forth in section
3-2-6 of this code.
§ 3-2-10 BID ACCOMPANIED BY CHECK OR BOND; DEFAULT; RETURN.
   (A)   Check or Bond Required. Each bidder on a public construction contract
shall accompany his bid by a certified or cashier’s check or bid bond equal to
five percent (5%) of the bid, which shall be deposited with the city as a
guaranty, and there shall be forfeited to the city cost of republication of
notice to bidders, all actual expenses incurred by reason of bidder’s default
and the difference between the low bid of the defaulting bidder and the amount
of the bid of the bidder to whom the contract is subsequently awarded, but not
to exceed the amount of the check or bid bond, in the event the apparently
successful bidder fails to execute the contract or fails to provide the
required bond and insurance to the city.
   (B)   Return to Bidder.
      (1)   The certified or cashier’s check or bid bond shall be returned to
the successful bidder on execution and delivery of the contract and required
bond and insurance.
      (2)   Checks of unsuccessful bidders shall be returned to them in
accordance with the terms of the proposal.
§ 3-2-11 DISCLOSURE STATEMENT REQUIRED.
   Each bidder shall accompany his bid with a written statement under oath
disclosing the following information:
   (A)   The nature of any partnership, joint venture or other business
relationships then in effect or which existed within one year prior to the date
of such statement with the architect, engineer or other party to the project;
   (B)   Any such business relationship then in effect or which existed within
one year prior to the date of such statement between any officer or director of
the bidding company and any officer or director of the architectural or
engineering firm or other party to the project;
   (C)   The names of all persons having any such business relationships and
the positions they hold with their respective companies or firms. If none of
the business relationships hereinabove mentioned exist, then a statement to
that effect; and
   (D)   A sworn statement that he has not been a party to any agreement or
collusion among bidders or prospective bidders in restraint of freedom of
competition by agreement to bid at a fixed price or to refrain from bidding or
otherwise.
§ 3-2-12 TIME FOR RECEIVING BIDS.
   Any bid received by the city or an officer or employee thereof, more than
ninety-six (96) hours, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, before the
time set for the opening of bids, or any bid so received after the time set for
opening of bids, shall not be considered by the city and shall be returned
unopened to the bidder submitting same.
§ 3-2-13 BID OPENING.
   All bids shall be sealed and opened only at the time and place mentioned in
the bid section, and read aloud in the presence of the City Council. Such bid
opening shall be open to the public and to all bidders.
§ 3-2-14 AWARD OF CONTRACT.
   (A)   Lowest Responsible Bidder. The awarding of a contract to the lowest
responsible bidder or bidders shall be made within thirty (30) days after the
opening of bids unless the City Council votes and records the same, for good
cause shown, to provide for an extension period. The extension period shall not
exceed fifteen (15) days where only state or local funds are involved, or more
than ninety (90) days where federal funds are involved.
   (B)   Other than Lowest Bidder. If an award is made to other than the lowest
bidder, the city shall accompany its action with a publicized statement setting
forth the reason for its action. Such statement shall be placed on file, open
to public inspection, and be a matter of public record.
§ 3-2-15 REJECTION OF BIDS.
   By majority action of the City Council, the city shall have the right to
reject any or all bids and solicit bidders again as herein provided, if, in the
opinion of the City Council, the best interests of the people of the city and
the state would be served by so doing.
§ 3-2-16 BIDS PUBLIC RECORD.
   All bids, both successful and unsuccessful, and all contracts and required
bonds shall be placed on file and maintained in the main office of the city for
a period of five (5) years from the date of opening of bids or for a period of
three (3) years from the date of completion of the contract, whichever is
longer, shall be open to public inspection and shall be matters of public
record.
§ 3-2-17 EXECUTION OF CONTRACT; DOCUMENTS REQUIRED.
   Within the period of time specified in the bid notices, not to exceed sixty
(60) days, a contract embodying the terms set forth in the bidding documents
shall be executed by the city and the successful bidder. The following shall be
provided by the contractor to the city.
   (A)   A bond complying with the provisions of 61 O.S. § 1;
   (B)   A good and sufficient bond in a sum equal to the contract price, with
adequate surety, to insure the proper and prompt completion of the work in
accordance with the provisions of the contract and bidding documents;
   (C)   A good and sufficient bond in a sum equal to the contract price to
protect the city against defective workmanship and materials for a period of
one year after acceptance of the project; and
   (D)   Public liability and workers’ compensation insurance during
construction in reasonable amounts. The city may require the contractor to name
the city and its architects and/or engineers as an additional assured under the
public liability insurance, which requirement, if made, shall be specifically
set forth in the bidding documents.
§ 3-2-18 INTEREST OF OFFICERS AND RELATIVES FORBIDDEN.
   The City Manager and members of the City Council authorizing or awarding or
supervising the execution of a public construction contract, and their
relatives within the third degree of consanguinity or affinity, are forbidden
to be interested directly or indirectly through stock ownership, partnership
interest or otherwise in any such contract. Contracts entered into in violation
of this provision shall be void.
§ 3-2-19 COLLUSION; PENALTIES; AFFIDAVIT.
   Any agreement or collusion among bidders or prospective bidders in restraint
of freedom of competition by agreement to bid at a fixed price or to refrain
from bidding, or otherwise, shall render the bids of such bidders void, and
persons willfully violating this provision shall be guilty of a felony. Each
bidder shall accompany his bid with a sworn statement that he has not been a
party to any such agreement. The form of the statement shall be substantially
as provided in 74 O.S. § 85.22, but modified in wording to refer to the city.
§ 3-2-20 PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES.
   (A)   Advance Disclosure of Bid Terms. Any disclosure in advance of the
terms of a bid submitted in response to a bid notice issued by the city is
unlawful and will render the proceeding void and require solicitation and award
anew.
   (B)   Soliciting Information in Preparing Bid. It is also unlawful for any
person to solicit, use, possess or receive such information for use in
preparing a bid unless the bid is withdrawn or the information is substantially
altered, in which case, notice thereof must be made uniformly known.
   (C)   Impede Disclosure or Distribution. After the date when such
information is to be made generally available, it shall be unlawful for any
person to withhold or impede its disclosure or distribution.
§ 3-2-21 NO TIMELY BID.
   If no timely bid is received after bid notices have been published on any
proposed public construction contract which does not exceed fifty thousand
dollars ($50,000.00), the City Council may direct its employees or agents to
negotiate the contract with a prospective contractor. The amount of a contract
which may be awarded by City Council pursuant to this section shall not exceed
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), and the work to be performed shall be as
specified in the initial bidding documents. The contract shall be executed
within six (6) months after the date initially set for opening of bids. The
contract and contract procedure shall conform to all other applicable
provisions of the public competitive bidding act of 1974.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 61 OS §§ 101 et seq.
§ 3-2-22 ASSIGNMENT OF CONTRACT BY BIDDER PROHIBITED.
   No public construction contract shall be assignable by the successful bidder
without written consent of the City Council, evidenced by resolution. In no
event shall such a contract be assigned to a bidder who was declared by the
city not to be a responsible bidder in the consideration of bids received for
the particular contract.
§ 3-2-23 CHANGE ORDER; CONTENTS.
   (A)   Contents. Change orders or addenda to public construction contracts of
one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) or less shall not exceed a fifteen percent
(15%) cumulative increase in the original contract amount. Change orders or
addenda to public construction contracts of over one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) shall not exceed the greater of one hundred fifty thousand
dollars ($150,000.00) or a ten percent (10%) cumulative increase in the total
of the original contract amount. Any change orders or cumulative change orders
which exceed these limits shall require a readvertising for bids on the
incomplete portions of the contract. Change orders in any amount shall be
formally approved by the City Council and the reasons therefor recorded in the
permanent records. All change orders shall contain a unit price and total for
each of the following items:
      (1)   All materials with cost per item;
      (2)   Itemization of all labor with number of hours per operation and
cost per hour;
      (3)   Itemization of all equipment with the type of equipment, number of
each type, cost per hour for each type, and number of hours of actual operation
for each type;
      (4)   Itemization of insurance cost, bond cost, social security, taxes,
workers’ compensation, employee fringe benefits and overhead cost; and
      (5)   Profit for the contractor.
   (B)   Exceptions.
      (1)   If a construction contract contains unit pricing, and the change
order pertains to the unit price, the change order will not be subject to this
section.
      (2)   When the unit price change does not exceed ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00), the unit price change order computation may be based on an
acceptable unit price basis in lieu of cost itemization as required in
subsections (A)(1) through (A)(5) of this section.
   (C)   Alternates or Add Items. Alternates or add items bid with the original
bid and contained in the awarded contract as options of the city shall not be
construed as change orders under the provisions of this chapter.
§ 3-2-24 INSURANCE.
   The city may, at its option, require the contractor to carry insurance
against damage from fire and the elements during the process of construction to
the extent of protecting the city’s equity in the project until accepted.
§ 3-2-25 CERTIFICATION OF INVOICES, EFFECT.
   All statements or invoices submitted to the city for work performed shall
contain a sworn certification by the supervising architect or engineer, or
other supervisory official if no supervisory architect or engineer is employed
for the project, that work for which payment is claimed has been performed and
that such work conforms to the plans and specifications for the project. No
such statement or invoice shall be paid by the city without such certification.
The execution of a sworn certificate, as herein provided, shall not constitute
a defense or in any other manner affect any cause or causes of action which the
city might otherwise have against the contractor for nonperformance of a public
construction contract.
§ 3-2-26 INSPECTION OF PROJECTS.
   The city shall make provision for the inspection of projects prior to
acceptance by the city and shall approve claims for payment only after proper
inspection has been made as provided in the plans and specifications for the
project.
§ 3-2-27 FORCE ACCOUNT AUTHORIZED.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent the city from doing
public construction work on a force account basis.
§ 3-2-28 EMERGENCY CONTRACTS.
   (A)   Definition. For the purpose of this section, EMERGENCY shall be
limited to conditions resulting from a sudden unexpected happening or
unforeseen occurrence or condition and situation wherein the public health or
safety is endangered.
   (B)   Notice and Bidding Not Required. The provisions of this chapter with
reference to notice and bids shall not apply to an emergency if:
      (1)   The City Council declares by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of all of the
members of the council that an emergency exists; or
      (2)   The City Manager declares an emergency exists and the contract does
not exceed seventy-five thousand dollars ($75,000.00) in amount; provided
however, that if the City Manager declares such an emergency, he shall notify
the City Council of such action within ten (10) days. Such notification shall
contain a statement of the reasons for his action and shall be recorded in the
official minutes of the council.
   (C)   Reasons Entered into Minutes. The reasons for declaring an emergency
and not complying with the provisions of this chapter shall be entered into the
official minutes of the City Council.
(Ord. 2002-01, passed 2-5-2002; Ord. 2023-02, passed 5-9-2023)
§ 3-2-29 FAVORING PARTICULAR INSURANCE OR SURETY COMPANIES.
   The city, nor any officer, agent or employee thereof, nor any person acting
or purporting to act on behalf of the city, nor an officer, agent or employee
thereof, shall, with respect to any public construction contract, require or
attempt to require a contractor or any subcontractor to make application to or
to procure or obtain from any particular insurance or surety company, agent or
broker, any of the bonds or insurance required by this chapter.
§ 3-2-30 EIGHT HOUR DAY; LABORERS, CONTRACTS.
   (A)   Laborers, Mechanics, Janitors.
      (1)   Eight (8) hours shall constitute a day’s work for all laborers,
workers, mechanics, janitors of public institutions or other persons now
employed or who may hereafter be employed by and in behalf of the city, except
in cases where it may be necessary to work for more than eight (8) hours per
calendar day for the protection of property or life. However, in all such
cases, laborers, workers, mechanics or other persons so employed and working to
exceed eight (8) hours per calendar day shall be paid on a basis of eight (8)
hours constituting a day’s work.
      (2)   Not less than the current rate of per diem wages in the locality
where the work is performed shall be paid laborers, workers, mechanics,
janitors of public institutions or other persons so employed by or on behalf of
the city. Laborers, workers, mechanics or other persons employed by contractors
or subcontractors in the execution of any contract or contracts with the city
shall be deemed to be employed by or on behalf of the city.
   (B)   Contracts.
      (1)   All contracts hereafter made by or on behalf of the city with any
corporation, person or persons, for the performance of any work, by or on
behalf of the city, shall be deemed and considered as made upon the basis of
eight (8) hours constituting a day’s work.
      (2)   It is unlawful for such corporation, person or persons to require,
aid, abet, assist, connive at, or permit any laborer, worker, mechanic, janitor
at public institutions, or other person to work more than eight (8) hours per
calendar day in doing such work, except in cases and upon the conditions
described in subsection (A) of this section.
      (3)   The provisions of this chapter in regard to hours worked per
calendar day shall not apply to the construction, reconstruction, maintenance,
or the production of local materials for: highways, roads, streets and all the
structures and drainage in connection therewith; sewer systems; waterworks
systems; dams and levies; canals, drainage ditches; airport grading, drainage,
surfacing; seeding and planting.
      (4)   Provided, that the provisions of this chapter will not prevent
employees from drawing time and a half for those hours worked over forty (40)
during any calendar week.
§ 3-2-31 PUBLIC BUILDINGS, SPECIFICATIONS FOR HANDICAPPED.
   (A)   Facilities Required; Standards.
      (1)   All plans and specifications for the erection of a public building
by the city or for any building erected through the use of public funds, shall
provide facilities for the handicapped.
      (2)   Such facilities shall conform with the standards prescribed by the
Americans with disabilities act (ADA), being 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et seq.
      (3)   Elevators shall be constructed and installed in the buildings to
the extent deemed feasible and financially reasonable to the city.
      (4)   After the effective date of this subsection (A), any building or
facility which would have been subject to the provisions of this section, but
for the fact that it was constructed prior to the effective date thereof, shall
be subject to the requirements of this section if: a) additions are made to
such building or facility in any twelve (12) month period which increase the
total floor area of such building or facility by twenty-five percent (25%) or
more; or b) if alterations or structural repairs are made to such building or
facility in any twelve (12) month period which affect twenty-five percent (25%)
or more of the total floor area of such building or facility.
   (B)   Approval of Plans and Specifications.
      (1)   All plans and specifications for the erection of public buildings
covered by subsection (A) of this section shall be submitted to the City
Council prior to bidding and awarding the contract.
      (2)   Such plans and specifications shall be checked for compliance with
this chapter, and no construction contract for any public building shall be
awarded unless and until the plans and specifications are approved as being in
compliance with this chapter by the City Council.
§ 3-2-32 ENFORCEMENT.
   This chapter shall be subject to the enforcement provisions contained in 61
O.S. §§ 101 et seq.
