Article B. Reserved
ARTICLE A. OCCUPATION TAX AND REGULATIONS
§ 4-2A-1 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this Code, words and phrases shall have the meaning as
defined pursuant to the Oklahoma Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, at 37A O.S. §§
1-101 et seq., as amended.
(Ord. 2018-06, passed 9-11-2018)
§ 4-2A-2 TAX LEVIED; LICENSING REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   The fee schedule hereinafter set forth, shall be levied and collected
by the City Clerk, or the Clerk’s designee, for the applicable license, fees,
permits or occupational tax levies, prior to the issuance of any such license
permit or conducting of the business of serving alcoholic beverages. The city’s
fee schedule contained in Title 1, Chapter 10,
Section 1 and following of the Chandler City Code is hereby amended to reflect
the fees set forth in Section (B) hereof. Nothing contained herein is intended
to impair the City’s ability to amend said fees by resolution.
   (B)   Occupational Taxes relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages (as
defined in 37A O.S. § 1-103) are as follows:
      (1)   Large Brewer: $1,250.00.
      (2)   Small Brewer: $125.00.
      (3)   Distiller: $3,125.00.
      (4)   Winemaker: $ 625.00.
      (5)   Oklahoma Winemaker: $75.00
      (6)   Rectifier: $3,125.00.
      (7)   Wholesaler (effective October 1, 2018 “Wine and Spirits
Wholesaler”): $3,500.00.
      (8)   Class B Wholesaler (effective October 1, 2018 “Beer Distributor”):
$625.00.
      (9)   Package Store: $500.00.
      (10)   Retail Wine (effective October 1, 2018): $500.00.
      (11)   Retail Beer (effective October 1, 2018): $500.00.
      (12)   Mixed Beverage: $1,005.00 - (Initial license); $905.00 -
(Renewal).
      (13)   Mixed Beverage (beer and wine only): $500.00.
      (14)   Mixed Beverage/Caterer Combination: $1,000.00.
      (15)   Special Event (Per Day): $100.00.
   (C)   Term of License; Payment of Fee.
      (1)   All licenses issued pursuant to this article shall expire on June
30 of the year for which it was issued. The tax hereby levied shall be paid no
later than the first day of July following the issuance or renewal of a liquor
license by the State of Oklahoma.
      (2)   The cost of a license of any type or class applied for during the
fiscal year shall be a pro rata part of the cost of the yearly license;
provided that the cost of the license shall be computed on a monthly basis.
Licenses issued on or after the fifteenth day of any month shall be charged for
on the basis of the first day of the next month.
      (3)   Failure to timely pay to the City any initial or renewal occupation
tax as required hereunder shall constitute a municipal offense, the penalty for
which upon conviction shall be punished in accordance with section 1-4-1(A) of
the Chandler City Code. Each day in which such tax remains due and unpaid shall
constitute a distinct and separate offense.
(Ord. 2018-06, passed 9-11-2018)
§ 4-2A-3 CERTIFICATES OF COMPLIANCE: APPLICATION AND ISSUANCE.
   (A)   It shall be the responsibility of the City Clerk to issue Certificates
of Compliance with the municipal zoning ordinances and health, safety and fire
codes as required by 37A O.S. Applicants shall furnish to the office of the
City Clerk such information as the City staff may require, together with a
bond, surety, cash, or other negotiable instrument sufficient to satisfy the
occupational tax imposed by this chapter. Said bond, surety, cash, or other
negotiable instrument shall be payable to the City of Chandler at such time as
the applicant is licensed by the ABLE Commission.
   (B)   An applicant’s proposed location and use thereof shall be in
conformance with the laws of the State of Oklahoma and with the ordinances of
the City of Chandler and shall pass all necessary health, safety and fire code
inspections or no Certificate of Compliance shall issue. The City Clerk shall
act with regard to the issuance or refusal of said Certificates of Compliance
within twenty (20) days after the receipt of an application therefore.
(Ord. 2018-06, passed 9-11-2018)
§ 4-2A-4 RESTRICTION ON LOCATION OF PACKAGE STORE, MIXED BEVERAGE ESTABLISHMENT
OR BEER AND WINE ESTABLISHMENT.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any package store, mixed beverage
establishment, beer and wine establishment or bottle club which has been
licensed by the ABLE Commission and which has as its main purpose the selling
or serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises, or package
store, to be located within three hundred (300) feet of any public or private
school or church property primarily and regularly used for worship services and
religious activities
   (B)   The distance indicated in this section shall be measured from the
nearest property line of such public or private school or church to the nearest
perimeter wall of the premises of any such mixed beverage establishment, beer
and wine establishment, bottle club or package store which has been licensed to
sell alcoholic beverages.
   (C)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
      (1)   Mixed beverage establishments, beer and wine establishments, or
bottle clubs, which have been licensed to sell alcoholic beverages for on-
premises consumption or retail package stores prior to November 1, 2000;
provided, if at the time of application for license renewal the licensed
location has not been in actual operation for a continuous period of more than
sixty (60) days, the license shall not be renewed; or
      (2)   Establishments licensed prior to October 1, 2018, to sell low-point
beer which were permitted to be located within three hundred (300) feet of any
public or private school or church property primarily and regularly used for
worship services and religious activities, pursuant to the provisions of 37
O.S. § 163.27. Such establishments shall be permitted to have any license in
effect on October 1, 2018, transferred to a mixed beverage license; provided,
if such an establishment ceases to regularly be open to the public or changes
ownership, the provisions of this paragraph shall cease to apply.
   (D)   If any school or church shall be established within three hundred
(300) feet of any package store, mixed beverage establishment, beer and wine
establishment or bottle club subject to the provisions of this section after
such package store, mixed beverage establishment, beer and wine establishment
or bottle club has been licensed, the provisions of this section shall not be a
deterrent to the renewal of such license if there has not been a lapse of more
than sixty (60) days. When any mixed beverage establishment, beer and wine
establishment or bottle club subject to the provisions of this section which
has a license to sell alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption, or
package store, changes ownership or the operator thereof is changed and such
change of ownership results in the same type of business being conducted on the
premises, the provisions of this section shall not be a deterrent to the
issuance of a license to the new owner or operator if he or she is otherwise
qualified.
(Ord. 2018-06, passed 9-11-2018)
§ 4-2A-5 REGULATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   From and after the effective date hereof all matters relating to the
regulation of alcoholic beverages shall be governed by the provisions of the
Alcohol Beverage Control Act, codified in 37A O.S., except as may be otherwise
provided for by the provisions of this Code.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person:
      (1)   (a)   To knowingly sell, deliver, or furnish alcoholic beverages to
any person under twenty-one (21) years of age;
      (2)   Who is under the age of twenty-one (21) to misrepresent his age in
writing or by presenting documentation of age for the purpose of inducing any
person to sell him alcoholic beverages;
      (3)   To knowingly sell, deliver, or furnish alcoholic beverages to an
intoxicated person or to any person who has been adjudged mentally deficient;
      (4)   To open a retail container or consume alcoholic beverages on the
premises of a retail package store; or for any operator of a retail package
store, or any person in charge thereof, to permit any person to open a retail
container therein or consume alcoholic beverages therein;
      (5)   To drink intoxicating liquor in public or to be intoxicated in a
public place; provided, however, the city council of the city shall be
authorized to waive the prohibition against consumption for specific events, or
types of events, upon proper application and under such conditions as the
council deems appropriate for such event or types of events.
(Ord. 2018-06, passed 9-11-2018)
ARTICLE B. RESERVED
   Reserved by Ord. 2018-06, passed 9-11-2018.
CHAPTER 3: TAXICABS
Section
   
4-3-1   License Required
   
4-3-2   License Fee; Insurance
   
4-3-3   Operator License Issuance
   
4-3-4   Inspection of Vehicles
   
4-3-5   Appeal from Denial or Revocation of License
   
4-3-6   Revocation of License
   
4-3-7   Penalty
§ 4-3-1 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of operating a
taxicab, motorcar, automobile, motor bus or other vehicle for the purpose of
transporting passengers for hire upon, over and through the streets, avenues,
thoroughfares or other public places within the city limits without having
first obtained a license to engage in such business from the city clerk.
§ 4-3-2 LICENSE FEE; INSURANCE.
   A license to operate a taxicab, motorcar, automobile, or motor bus business
within the city, or upon the streets and public ways may be issued by the city
clerk to any person, firm or corporation of good moral character attested to by
the affidavit of two (2) residents of the city, who shall apply by submitting
the following:
   (A)   Fee. A license fee as established by the city’s fee schedule, the
license to terminate on June 30, next, thereafter;
   (B)   Certificate of Insurance. A certificate from an insurance company
licensed to do business within the state not cancelable without ten (10) days’
notice to the city, indemnifying the city or any person to whom the applicant
may become liable in such amount as established by the city’s fee schedule.
   (C)   List of Vehicles and Operators; Proof of Insurance. A list of the
motor vehicles to be used in the business, duly showing that they, and each of
them, are covered by the insurance mentioned in this section and a list of
operators who are to operate the motor vehicles.
§ 4-3-3 OPERATOR LICENSE ISSUANCE.
   A license for the driving and operating of such motor vehicles for hire
within the city shall be issued to any person of good moral character, attested
to by the affidavits of two (2) residents of the city, who has not had his
motor vehicle operator’s license or commercial chauffeur’s license revoked by
the commissioner of public safety of the state or his counterpart in any other
state within three (3) years immediately prior to the date of the application
and who has not been convicted of a felony, which information shall be attested
to by the chief of police according to his best knowledge, and who shall:
   (A)   Exhibit to the city clerk proof of his being the holder of a valid
commercial chauffeur’s license by the state; and
   (B)   Submit to the city clerk a recent photograph not less than one inch by
one inch (1" x 1") and not larger than two inches by four inches (2" x 4") in
size for attachment to a license for such driver, and the license shall be
permanently and visibly displayed at all times in the taxicab or motor vehicle
operated by the driver for hire.
§ 4-3-4 INSPECTION OF VEHICLES.
   (A)   Requirement. Every person, firm or corporation obtaining a license
hereunder shall, at least twice in each calendar year, have each vehicle so
used inspected for operational safety and furnish the city clerk proof of the
safe condition of each vehicle.
   (B)   Inspection Authorized. The chief of police of the city or any highway
patrol officer of this state shall be deemed qualified to conduct the
inspection.
§ 4-3-5 APPEAL FROM DENIAL OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   Issuance or revocation of, or refusal to issue, the foregoing license or
permits, and each of them, by the city clerk may be appealed to the city
council, by any citizen of the city, or person, firm or corporation aggrieved.
§ 4-3-6 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The license shall be revoked immediately upon termination of required
insurance, failing to keep the list of automotive equipment and drivers up to
date in the office of the city clerk or for good cause shown.
§ 4-3-7 PENALTY.
   Any breach of this chapter by: a) failing to obtain the license; b)
operating without a license; or c) failing to prominently and visibly display
the same, shall constitute a breach of the ordinances of the city and shall be
punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. Each day of such
operation without a license, insurance or operator’s license, shall constitute
a separate breach and offense.
CHAPTER 4: PEDDLERS, CANVASSERS, SOLICITORS AND ITINERANT VENDORS
Section
   
4-4-1   Definitions
   
4-4-2   License Required
   
4-4-3   Application for License
   
4-4-4   Revocation of License
   
4-4-5   Duty of Solicitors
   
4-4-6   Exceptions
   
4-4-7   Time Limit on Soliciting
   
4-4-8   Fees
   
4-4-9   Identification Tag, Display
   
4-4-10   Enforcement
   
4-4-11   Penalties for Violation
§ 4-4-1 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   APPLICANT. A person or entity seeking to obtain a license for solicitation
from the city of Chandler.
   LICENSED SOLICITOR. Shall mean and include any person who has obtained a
valid solicitor’s license as hereinafter provided, which certificate is in the
possession of the solicitor on his or her person while engaged in soliciting.
   NONRESIDENTIAL PREMISES. Includes all buildings, structures, and units in
the city of Chandler occupied for nonresidential purposes.
   RESIDENCE. Shall mean and include every separate living unit occupied for
residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of
building or structure.
   SOLICITING. Shall mean and include any one or more of the following
activities:
      (1)   Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares,
merchandise, foodstuffs, or services of any kind, character or description
whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever; or
      (2)   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase
of insurance of any type, kind or publication; or
      (3)   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals,
newspapers and every other kind of publication; or
      (4)   Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any
other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit
association, organization, corporation, or project; or
      (5)   Seeking to canvass the residents of the city of Chandler;
      (6)   Seeking to advertise, promote or sell any product, goods or
services;
      (7)   Seeking to hand out, place or distribute upon private property
handbills or other written material advertising goods or services for sale.
(Ord. 2009-02, passed 4-14-2009)
§ 4-4-2 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   Except as exempted herein, each itinerant vendor, canvasser, solicitor or
peddler shall obtain a solicitor’s license from the city of Chandler prior to
any soliciting within the corporate limits of the city.
(Ord. 2009-02, passed 4-14-2009)
§ 4-4-3 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Applicants for licenses shall make application with the city clerk during
regular business hours upon an application form provided by the city of
Chandler and signed by the applicant if an individual, by all partners if a
partnership, and by a qualified corporate officer if a corporation, providing,
as a minimum, the information required in this section. The applicant shall
truthfully state and provide in full the following information, or no license
shall issue:
   (A)   Name and address of present place of residence and length of residence
at such address; also a business address if other than present address;
   (B)   Address of place of residence during the past three (3) years if other
than present address;
   (C)   Age of applicant;
   (D)   Physical description of the applicant;
   (E)   Name and address of the person, firm or corporation or association
whom the applicant is employed by or represents; and the length of time of such
employment or representation;
   (F)   Name and address of employer during the past three (3) years if other
than the present employer;
   (G)   The nature of the goods or products being sold, that is whether they
are “seconds”, rejects or first line quality, and whether or not any warranty
applies to the items being sold; if a warranty applies, the period of the
warranty and the name and address of the warrantor and the procedures for
filing for the adjustment of refund or return of goods shall be specified;
   (H)   Period of time for which the license is applied;
   (I)   The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application for
license under this chapter, if any;
   (J)   Has a license issued to the applicant under this chapter ever been
revoked?
   (K)   Has the applicant ever been convicted of a violation of a felony under
the laws of the state of Oklahoma or any other state or federal law of the
United States?
   (L)   Names of the three (3) most recent communities where the applicant has
solicited;
   (M)   Proposed method of operation;
   (N)   Signature of applicant;
   (O)   Social Security number of applicant;
   (P)   Driver’s license number of applicant;
   (Q)   A statement that the applicant agrees to the requirement to pay all
state and city sales taxes due on all items which are subject to sales taxes
and recognizes that a copy of all applications will be provided to the local
office of the Oklahoma tax commission;
   (R)   Copy of a current Oklahoma sales tax permit; and
   (S)   A photograph of each person who will be soliciting under the
applicant. Photographs shall have been taken no more than sixty (60) days
immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, and shall show
the head and shoulders of the person(s) in a clear and distinguishing manner.
      All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in
connection therewith shall be under oath.
      The city clerk shall cause to be kept at city hall an accurate record of
every application received and acted upon together with all other information
and data pertaining thereto and all licenses issued under the provisions of
this chapter, and of the denial of applications.
      No license shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the
commission of a felony (except crimes relating to political protest) under the
laws of the state of Oklahoma or any other state or federal law of the United
States, within five (5) years of the date of the application; nor to any person
who has been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter;
nor any person whose license has been revoked as herein provided.
(Ord. 2009-02, passed 4-14-2009)
§ 4-4-4 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   Any license issued hereunder shall be revoked if the holder of the license
is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or has
made a false material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes
disqualified for the issuance of a license under the terms of this chapter.
Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the
city of Chandler to the holder of the license in person or by certified United
States mail addressed to his or her residence address set forth in the
application.
   Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the license shall become null
and void.
(Ord. 2009-02, passed 4-14-2009)
§ 4-4-5 DUTY OF SOLICITORS.
   It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going onto any premises in the
city of Chandler upon which a “residence” as herein defined is located, to
first examine the door for any posted notices. If there is a notice stating “No
Solicitors”, then the solicitor, whether licensed or not, shall immediately and
peacefully depart from the premises and shall not leave any material,
merchandise, or literature whatsoever on the premises.
   Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or
not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested
to do so by the occupant.
(Ord. 2009-02, passed 4-14-2009)
§ 4-4-6 EXCEPTIONS.
   The following are exempt from all license and fee requirements of this
chapter:
   (A)   Charitable Organizations. For the purpose of this subsection (A),
CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION means any nonprofit, tax exempt, charitable, education,
religious or government organization as those terms are defined by applicable
state and federal laws.
   (B)   Political Canvassing. Solicitations exclusively intended to canvass or
petition for a public official, political candidate, public policy or
initiative being promoted for purposes of a public referendum, initiative, or
election.
(Ord. 2009-02, passed 4-14-2009)
§ 4-4-7 TIME LIMIT ON SOLICITING.
   It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute an offense for any
person whether licensed under this chapter or not, to go upon any premises and
ring the doorbell of a residence located therein, or rap or knock upon any door
or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of
the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with
the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting as herein defined, except between
the following hours:
   (A)   May 1 to September 30: Eight o’clock (8:00) A.M. to nine o’clock (9:
00) P.M.
   (B)   October 1 to April 30: Eight o’clock (8:00) A.M. to seven o’clock (7:
00) P.M.
(Ord. 2009-02, passed 4-14-2009)
§ 4-4-8 FEES.
   The fees for licenses herein required shall be as established by the city’s
fee schedule.
   (A)   Fees prescribed herein shall not be refunded to any business operating
for less than the full period to which the fee applies.
(Ord. 2009-02, passed 4-14-2009)
§ 4-4-9 IDENTIFICATION TAG, DISPLAY.
   The license shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the area where the
solicitor’s business is to be conducted, or otherwise hung from the vehicle
mirror or carried upon the person of such vendor who is soliciting within the
city of Chandler.
(Ord. 2009-02, passed 4-14-2009)
§ 4-4-10 ENFORCEMENT.
   The building inspector, compliance officer, or other municipal law
enforcement officer shall enforce this chapter and shall have the authority to
issue citations to any person, firm, or corporation which violates, in any
manner, this chapter.
(Ord. 2009-02, passed 4-14-2009)
§ 4-4-11 PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION.
   (A)   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter, or who
disobeys, omits, neglects, or refuses to comply with, or resists enforcement
of, any section of this chapter, is subject to payment of a fine as established
by the city, plus costs, for each violation.
   (B)   Repeat offenses under this chapter shall be subject to increased fines
as provided by this subsection, below. As used in this section, a REPEAT
OFFENSE is defined as a second or subsequent violation of the same requirement
or provision of this chapter within a one year period. The increased fine for a
repeat offense under this chapter shall be as follows:
      (1)   The fine for any offense which is a first repeat offense shall be
as established by the city, plus costs.
      (2)   The fine for any offense which is a second or subsequent offense,
shall be as established by the city, plus costs.
   (C)   Each day on which any violation of this chapter occurs or continues
constitutes a separate offense subject to separate penalties.
(Ord. 2009-02, passed 4-14-2009)
CHAPTER 5: MEDICAL MARIJUANA FACILITIES
Section
   
4-5-1   Definitions
   
4-5-2   Retail Medical Marijuana Dispensaries
   
4-5-3   Retail Medical Marijuana Dispensary Location Restrictions
   
4-5-4   Commercial Medical Marijuana Growing Facilities
   
4-5-5   Commercial Medical Marijuana Growing Facilities Location Restrictions
   
4-5-6   Commercial Medical Marijuana Processing Facilities
   
4-5-7   Commercial Medical Marijuana Processing Facilities Location
Restrictions
   
4-5-8   Inspections
   
4-5-9   Other Regulations
   
4-5-10   Penalties
§ 4-5-1 DEFINITIONS.
   All medical marijuana facilities permitted by this ordinance are hereby
defined as any such facility which is properly licensed by the State of
Oklahoma.
(Ord. 2018-05, passed 9-20-2018)
§ 4-5-2 RETAIL MEDICAL MARIJUANA DISPENSARIES.
   (A)   All operators of retail medical marijuana dispensaries are required to
obtain a Retail Medical Marijuana Dispensary permit from the Municipal Clerk.
   (B)   The Retail Medical Marijuana Dispensary permit fee shall be six
hundred dollars ($600.00) per year. The fee shall be used to offset municipal
expenses covering costs related to licensing, inspection, administration and
enforcement of retail medical marijuana dispensaries.
(Ord. 2018-05, passed 9-20-2018)
§ 4-5-3 RETAIL MEDICAL MARIJUANA DISPENSARY LOCATION RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   A Retail Medical Marijuana Dispensary permit will not be granted to
any applicant where the proposed location is outside of a commercial zone of
the corporate city limits of Chandler.
   (B)   A Retail Medical Marijuana Dispensary permit will not be granted to
any applicant where the proposed location would be situated within one thousand
(1,000) feet of any public or private elementary, middle, or high school.
   (C)   For the distance requirement outlined in subsection (B), the distance
shall be computed by direct measurement in a straight line from the nearest
property line of the parcel of land on which the use described in Section
4-5-3(B) is located to the main entrance of the public or private school.
(Ord. 2018-05, passed 9-20-2018)
§ 4-5-4 COMMERCIAL MEDICAL MARIJUANA GROWING FACILITIES.
   (A)   All operators of a commercial medical marijuana growing facility are
required to obtain a Commercial Medical Marijuana Growing Facility permit from
the Municipal Clerk.
   (B)   The Medical Marijuana Growing Facility permit fee shall be six hundred
dollars ($600.00) per year. The fee shall be used to offset municipal expenses
covering costs related to licensing, inspection, administration and enforcement
of commercial medical marijuana growing facilities.
(Ord. 2018-05, passed 9-20-2018)
§ 4-5-5 COMMERCIAL MEDICAL MARIJUANA GROWING FACILITIES LOCATION RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   A Commercial Medical Marijuana Growing Facility permit will not be
granted to any applicant where the proposed location is outside of an
Industrial or Agricultural zone, or such other zone as may hereinafter
specifically permit the same.
   (B)   A Commercial Medical Marijuana Growing permit will not be granted to
any applicant where the proposed location would be situated within one thousand
(1,000) feet of any public or private elementary, middle, or high school.
   (C)   For the distance requirement outlined in subsection (B), the distance
shall be computed by direct measurement in a straight line from the nearest
property line of the parcel of land on which the use described in Section
4-5-5(B) is located to the main entrance of the public or private school.
   (D)   A commercial medical marijuana growing facility must be constructed in
such a manner that the growing of the marijuana plants cannot be seen by the
public from a public right-of-way.
(Ord. 2018-05, passed 9-20-2018)
§ 4-5-6 COMMERCIAL MEDICAL MARIJUANA PROCESSING FACILITIES.
   (A)   All operators of a medical marijuana processing facility are required
to obtain a Medical Marijuana Processing Facility permit from the Municipal
Clerk.
   (B)   The Medical Marijuana Processing Facility permit fee shall be six
hundred dollars ($600.00) per year. The fee shall be used to offset municipal
expenses covering costs related to licensing, inspection, administration and
enforcement of commercial medical marijuana processing facilities.
(Ord. 2018-05, passed 9-20-2018)
§ 4-5-7 COMMERCIAL MEDICAL MARIJUANA PROCESSING FACILITIES LOCATION
RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   A Commercial Medical Marijuana Processing Facility permit will not be
granted to any applicant where the proposed location is outside an Industrial
or Agricultural zone or such other zone as may hereinafter specifically permit
the same.
   (B)   A Commercial Medical Marijuana Processing permit will not be granted
to any applicant where the proposed location would be situated within one
thousand (1,000) feet of any public or private elementary, middle, or high
school.
   (C)   For the distance requirement outlined in subsection (B), the distance
shall be computed by direct measurement in a straight line from the nearest
property line of the parcel of land on which the use described in Section
4-5-7(B) is located to the main entrance of the public or private school.
   (D)   A commercial medical marijuana processing facility must be constructed
in such a manner that the growing of the marijuana plants cannot be seen by the
public from the public right-of-way.
(Ord. 2018-05, passed 9-20-2018)
§ 4-5-8 INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   All permits outlined in this ordinance will be subject to inspection
by an authorized municipal inspector prior to issuance.
   (B)   The inspection prior to a permit decision will occur at a time
scheduled and approved by both the applicant and the municipal inspector.
   (C)   The applicant will be required to be present during the inspection.
   (D)   After a medical marijuana facility permit has been issued under this
Chapter, the City’s permitting authority, or agent thereof, shall be authorized
to enter upon and inspect the operations being conducted therein to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this ordinance. Such inspection shall take
place during regular business hours of such facility and upon reasonable notice
to the operator of such facility.
(Ord. 2018-05, passed 9-20-2018)
§ 4-5-9 OTHER REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The City of Chandler hereby adopts those regulations governing
commercial medical-marijuana businesses as have been, and may be, codified in
310 OAC Chapter 681, as that Chapter may be amended from time to time. The
provisions of said chapter of the OAC, shall take effect and be controlling
within the City’s limits such that a violation of those regulations shall be a
violation of this Code, though nothing in this Section shall grant to the city
the power or jurisdiction to prosecute offenses that a city is not authorized
to prosecute. Copies of 310 OAC Chapter 681 shall be available in the City
Clerk’s office.
   (B)   A plan for ventilation of a medical-marijuana-business facility shall
be submitted to the City prior to a permit being granted and shall describe to
the City’s satisfaction the ventilation systems that will be used to prevent
any unreasonable odor of marijuana from escaping the facility.
   (C)   Fire separation and suppression. A plan for fire separation at a
medical-marijuana-business facility shall be submitted to the City prior to a
permit being granted and shall describe to the City’s satisfaction the manner
by which any fire generated at such facility shall be contained within and
prevented from spreading to any adjacent structures. The same plan shall
describe to the City’s satisfaction the manner by which any such fire within
the facility shall be suppressed.
   (D)   Use of marijuana on public property. Smoking or using marijuana shall
be prohibited on all city property including vehicles, buildings, parks or
other city facilities.
(Ord. 2018-05, passed 9-20-2018)
§ 4-5-10 PENALTIES.
   Penalties for violations of this Chapter shall be, in the City’s discretion,
a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200) per day of violation, or
revocation of permit, or both. Each day that a violation continues shall be
considered a separate offense. The dollar amount of the fine imposed hereby is
subject to amendment by resolution of the City’s fee schedule.
(Ord. 2018-05, passed 9-20-2018)
TITLE 5: PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY
