8-1-7   Drainage of Water or Pollutants
   
8-1-8   Hazardous Conditions
   
8-1-9   Excavations
   
8-1-10   Penalty
§ 8-1-1 TREES AND SHRUBBERY.
   (A)   Trimming Trees and Shrubbery.
      (1)   Trimming Required.
         (a)   The owner of any premises abutting on any street shall trim all
trees and shrubbery growing in the parking, between the sidewalks and the
roadway, of any such street, and all trees and shrubbery growing on any part of
the premises adjacent to the sidewalks or any street or alley, in such manner
that the boughs or limbs thereof shall not obstruct free and convenient
passage, travel and view along the streets, sidewalks, and alleys.
         (b)   When such premises are occupied by some person other than the
owner, such occupant shall trim the trees and shrubbery in the same manner as
hereinbefore required of the owner.
         (c)   Such trees or shrubbery shall be trimmed so that the lowest
branches or foliage shall not be lower than ten feet (10') above the roadway of
a street or alley, nor lower than eight feet (8') above the sidewalk.
      (2)   Failure to Trim; City Abatement; Hearing; Lien.
         (a)   Any owner or occupant who fails, refuses, or neglects to trim
trees and shrubbery as provided in subsection (A)(1) of this section, after
receiving a ten (10) day notice from the chief of police to do so, shall be
guilty of an offense. Every day that the owner or occupant fails, refuses, or
neglects to trim such trees or shrubbery, after the expiration of the ten (10)
day notice, shall be a separate offense.
         (b)   The owner of the property may give his written consent to the
city authorizing the removal of trees and shrubbery. By giving such written
consent, the owner waives his right to a hearing by the city council.
         (c)   A hearing may be held by the city council to determine whether
the tree or shrubbery has caused the property to become detrimental to the
health, benefit, and welfare of the public and the community or a hazard to
traffic or creates a fire hazard to the danger of property.
         (d)   Upon a finding that the condition of the property constitutes a
detriment or hazard, and that the property would be benefitted by the removal
of such tree or shrubbery, the agents of the city are granted the right of
entry on the property for the removal of trees or shrubbery, and performance of
the necessary duties as a governmental function of the city.
         (e)   The city council shall determine the actual cost of such removal
of a tree and any other expenses as may be necessary in connection therewith,
including the cost of notice and mailing. The city clerk shall forward by
certified mail with return receipt requested to the property owner at the
address shown by the current year’s tax rolls in the county treasurer’s office
a statement of such actual cost and demanding payment. If the tree removal is
done by the city, the cost to the property owner for the removal shall not
exceed the actual cost of the labor, maintenance, and equipment required for
removal. If the removal is done on a private contract basis, the contract shall
be awarded to the lowest and best bidder.
         (f)   If payment is not made within thirty (30) days from the date of
the mailing of the statement, the city clerk shall forward a certified
statement of the amount of the cost to the county treasurer of the county in
which the property is located and the same shall be levied on the property and
collected by the county treasurer as other taxes authorized by law. The cost
and the interest thereon shall be a lien against the property from the date the
cost is certified to the county treasurer, coequal with the lien of ad valorem
taxes and all other taxes and special assessments and prior and superior to all
other titles and liens against the property, and the lien shall continue until
the cost shall be fully paid. At any time prior to the collection as provided
in this subsection, the city may pursue any civil remedy for collection of the
amount owing and interest thereon. Upon receiving payment, if any, the city
clerk shall forward to the county treasurer a notice of such payment and
directing discharge of the lien.
   (B)   Injuring Trees and Shrubbery. It is unlawful for any person to injure
any tree or shrubbery in a street or alley. This subsection shall not prohibit
the lawful and proper care and removal of such trees and shrubbery.
§ 8-1-2 OBSTRUCTING PUBLIC WAYS WITH MERCHANDISE.
   (A)   Placing Merchandise on Public Ways. It is unlawful for any person,
firm or corporation to place upon or permit to be placed upon parkways, streets
and alleys, any goods, wares, articles of merchandise, or any other
obstruction, and leave same thereon; or to use the same as a place to carry on
a business or trade.
   (B)   Interference with Pedestrian or Vehicular Traffic. It is unlawful for
any person, firm or corporation to use or obstruct sidewalks more than one-half
(1/2) from the building in any manner so as to interfere unduly with pedestrian
traffic thereon, or to use or obstruct streets and alleys in any manner so as
to interfere unduly with lawful traffic and parking thereon.
§ 8-1-3 DEPOSITING TRASH ON STREETS OR SIDEWALKS.
   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to deposit, throw, or
sweep into or upon streets, alleys, parkings or sidewalks any paper, rubbish,
grass, weeds, tree trimmings, dirt, trash, crates, boxes, or other refuse of
any kind.
§ 8-1-4 INTERFERENCE WITH DRAINAGE.
   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to obstruct any street,
sidewalk or alley by placing any approach driveway or other obstruction or
substance whatever that will obstruct or prevent the natural flow of water into
the storm sewers or drains, or dam the same so as to back any water upon the
streets, alleys, sidewalks, or gutters.
§ 8-1-5 PLAYING ON STREETS OR SIDEWALKS.
   It is unlawful for any person to play on sidewalks or upon the main traveled
portion of streets and alleys, except as may be authorized by ordinance.
§ 8-1-6 WASHING VEHICLES ON STREETS.
   (A)   Washing Prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to wash an
automobile or any other vehicle in any street and it is hereby prohibited.
   (B)   Disposal of Water, Mud or Trash from Vehicles.
      (1)   Disposal of water or mud from a vehicle shall drain to approved
storm drainage. Any dirt or mud shall be disposed of by returning same to the
yard.
      (2)   Trash removed during the washing shall be disposed of in a trash
receptacle.
§ 8-1-7 DRAINAGE OF WATER OR POLLUTANTS.
   (A)   Water from Filling Stations. It is unlawful for any owner or operator
of a filling station or other place of business, or any agent or employee
thereof, to cause or allow water, grease, or other fluid to flow or drain into,
upon, over, or across any sidewalk, parking, street, alley, or other public
way.
   (B)   Polluting Substances. It is unlawful for any residence or business to
allow drainage of a polluting substance into any street, alley or sidewalk. For
the purpose of this section, a POLLUTING SUBSTANCE is one defined under state
law, 82 O.S. § 1084.2.
§ 8-1-8 HAZARDOUS CONDITIONS.
   (A)   Adjacent Property Owner or Occupant Responsible. It is unlawful for
any owner or occupant of property abutting upon a sidewalk or sidewalk area to
permit the sidewalk or sidewalk area adjacent to the property to become a
hazard to persons using the sidewalk or sidewalk area. Such area shall be
cleaned upon notification by city authorities.
   (B)   Open Grating. It is unlawful and an offense for any person to permit
to be open or leave open any cellar door, manhole or grating of any kind in or
upon any street, sidewalk or alley of the city.
§ 8-1-9 EXCAVATIONS.
   It is unlawful for any person to make any excavation or cutting in any
street, sidewalk, alley or public grounds or to remove any earth or
construction material therefrom, except when so authorized to do so by the
city.
§ 8-1-10 PENALTY.
   Any violation of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be punishable as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code.
CHAPTER 2: LIBRARY AND LIBRARY BOARD
Section
   
8-2-1   Intent
   
8-2-2   Library Established
   
8-2-3   Library Board
   
8-2-4   Powers and Duties
   
8-2-5   Annual Report by Librarian
   
8-2-6   Appropriations
§ 8-2-1 INTENT.
   It is the desire and intent of the city council to provide a public library
service to the residents of the city, for the benefit of the city, the state,
and the nation.
§ 8-2-2 LIBRARY ESTABLISHED.
   The Chandler public library is hereby established.
§ 8-2-3 LIBRARY BOARD.
   (A)   Appointment; Compensation.
      (1)   The Chandler public library shall be governed by a board of five
(5) members appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council.
Appointments to the library board shall be made on the basis of ability,
understanding of the total responsibilities and objectives of public libraries,
and an active interest in the attainment of these goals.
      (2)   All library board members shall serve thereon without compensation.
   (B)   Terms. The board members shall hold office as follows: initial
appointments shall be for one one-year term, two (2) two-year terms, and two
(2) three-year terms. Subsequent appointments shall be for three (3) year terms
except in the case of an appointment to fill a vacancy, which appointment shall
be for the remainder of the unexpired term which is vacant. All terms of
initial and succeeding appointees shall expire on April 30 of the designated
year.
   (C)   Removal of Members. Any board member may be removed by the appointing
authority for misconduct, failure to attend board meetings, or other neglect of
duty.
   (D)   Officers, Rules. Immediately after the initial appointments, and
annually thereafter, the library board members shall meet and organize by an
election of one of their members as chairman, and by the election of such other
officers as they deem necessary. They may adopt such laws, rules and
regulations for their own guidance and for the government of the library as may
be expedient and not inconsistent with this chapter and the laws of the state.
(Ord. 1995-02, passed 5-1-1995)
§ 8-2-4 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   City Manager. The city manager shall appoint a librarian and shall
recommend an annual budget to the city council.
   (B)   Library Board.
      (1)   The library board shall set the policies of the library to accept
or decline gifts, and administer the expenditure of funds received from
appropriations, gifts and grants.
      (2)   The library board may contract for and receive funds available to
it for library purposes from the United States, the state, and any agency or
instrumentalities of these entities.
§ 8-2-5 ANNUAL REPORT BY LIBRARIAN.
   The librarian shall submit an annual financial and statistical report to the
mayor and city council and, if necessary, to the state department of libraries
for each fiscal year ending June 30. The report shall include an accounting for
monies received and expended and such other statistics about library use,
collections and staff which may be deemed necessary to account for their trust,
by July 31, of the same year.
§ 8-2-6 APPROPRIATIONS.
   The mayor and city council shall annually appropriate to the library board
from funds available to the city such monies as are deemed necessary to operate
and maintain the public library for the education and cultural enrichment of
the citizens of the city.
CHAPTER 3: CEMETERY
Section
   
8-3-1   Cemetery Policy
   
8-3-2   Definitions
   
8-3-3   General Rules; Enforcement
   
8-3-4   Cemetery Lots
   
8-3-5   Interments
   
8-3-6   Plants and Shrubs
§ 8-3-1 CEMETERY POLICY.
   For the mutual protection of lot owners and the cemetery as a whole, the
following rules and regulations have been adopted by the city as the rules and
regulations of city cemetery, and all lot owners and visitors within the
cemetery and all lots sold shall be subject to the rules and regulations; and
subject further, to such other rules and regulations, amendments or alterations
as shall be adopted by the city council from time to time, and the reference to
these rules and regulations in the deed or certificate of ownership to a lot
shall have the same force and effect as if set forth therein.
§ 8-3-2 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CEMETERY. Includes a burial park for earth interments, a community mausoleum
for vault or crypt interments, a crematory or crematorium and columbarium for
cinerary interments, or a combination of one or more than one thereof.
   CERTIFICATE OF OWNERSHIP. Applies to the original conveyance given by the
cemetery to the original purchaser.
   CRYPT. Includes an underground chamber or vault serving as a burial place.
   INTERMENT. The permanent disposition of the remains of a deceased person by
cremation and inurnment, entombment, or burial.
   LOT. Applies to numbered divisions as shown on the record plat which
consists of two (2) or more plots.
   LOT MARKER. A type of post used by the cemetery to locate corners of the lot
or plot.
   MAUSOLEUM. Includes a large, imposing tomb or small building serving as a
burial place.
   MEMORIAL. A monument, marker, tablet, headstone, tombstone, urn and crypt
and niche place.
   MONUMENT. Includes a tombstone or memorial of granite or marble which shall
extend above the surface of the ground.
   PLOT. Applies to a space of sufficient size to accommodate one adult
interment approximately three feet by ten feet (3' x 10').
   TEMPORARY MARKER. Includes markers made of synthetic or metallic materials
such as wood, plastic, tin as obtained from funeral homes or other sources.
§ 8-3-3 GENERAL RULES; ENFORCEMENT.
   (A)   Rules Established. The city owns and operates the city cemetery in
accordance with the laws of the state and city. The following rules shall also
govern the cemetery and its maintenance, operations and grounds:
      (1)   Employees of the city are not expected to work on Saturdays,
Sundays, or holidays, except when absolutely necessary in the preservation of
order, and as specified in the cemetery rules and regulations. Consequently,
funerals on Sundays and holidays will be permitted only in emergencies.
      (2)   Employees of the city are not permitted to do any work for lot
owners except upon order of the cemetery superintendent but are required to be
civil and courteous to all visitors.
      (3)   All fees or charges for services are payable at the city clerk’s
office as herein stated and patrons of the cemetery are requested not to pay
any fee or gratuity to any employee.
      (4)   Persons within the cemetery shall use only the avenues, roads,
walks and alleys, and no one is permitted to walk upon or across lots or lawns
unless it be necessary to do so to gain access to one’s own lot. The cemetery
expressly disclaims liability for any injuries sustained by anyone violating
this rule.
      (5)   Persons visiting the cemetery or attending funerals are strictly
prohibited from picking flowers, wild or cultivated, breaking or injuring any
tree, shrub, or plant, or from writing upon, defacing or injuring any memorial,
fence, or other structure within the cemetery grounds.
      (6)   Motor cars and vehicles must be kept under complete control at all
times. When meeting a funeral procession, they must stop until the procession
passes. They must not pass a funeral procession going in the same direction.
Motor cars must not be left with the engine running, and the emergency brakes
must be set when the driver is not in his seat. Mufflers must not be opened nor
the horn sounded within the cemetery.
      (7)   The following activities are prohibited:
         (a)   The driving of motor cars or other vehicles through the gates or
in the cemetery at speeds exceeding five (5) miles per hour;
         (b)   Driving any motor car, vehicle or animal across or upon any
grave, lot or lawn or parking or leaving the same thereon;
         (c)   Parking or leaving any motor car or vehicle on any road or
driveway within the cemetery at such location or in such position as to prevent
any other car or vehicle from passing the same, and if so parked or left, the
management will remove the car or vehicle; and
         (d)   Making a complete or partial reverse turn of any motor car or
vehicle on any road or driveway within the cemetery.
      (8)   Children under fifteen (15) years of age are not permitted within
the cemetery, or its buildings, unless accompanied by proper persons to take
care of them.
      (9)   Receptacles for waste materials are located at convenient places;
therefore, the throwing of rubbish on the drives and paths, or on any part of
the grounds, or in the buildings, is prohibited.
      (10)   The placing of boxes, shells, toys, metal designs, ornaments,
chairs, settees, vases and similar articles upon plots will not be permitted,
and, if so placed, the management reserves the right to remove them. The
following are exceptions:
         (a)   Memorial Day, when flowers, metal boxes, ornaments, glass vases,
and similar objects will be allowed; however, they must be removed within three
(3) days.
         (b)   On Christmas, when blankets and decorations will be allowed, and
they must be removed by January 15.
         (c)   All other exceptions must be cleared by the cemetery
superintendent or city manager.
         Personal property removed by the city manager will be retained for
thirty (30) days after removal so that property owners may claim their property
if they so desire.
      (11)   It is of the utmost importance that there should be strict
observance of the proprieties in the cemetery. Therefore, all persons within
the cemetery should avoid conduct unbecoming a sacred place, as follows:
         (a)   Loud or boisterous talking;
         (b)   Being about the grounds or in any of the buildings;
         (c)   Bringing lunches or refreshments into the cemetery or consuming
them on the grounds;
         (d)   Peddling or soliciting the sale of any commodity within the
cemetery;
         (e)   Placing of signs or notices or advertisements of any kind within
the cemetery;
         (f)   Bringing dogs into the cemetery or any of the buildings; and
         (g)   Bringing firearms into the cemetery except as authorized by
state law which preempts local law pursuant to 21 O.S. § 1289.4, or by a
military escort accompanying a veteran’s funeral or attending memorial
services.
      (12)   It is the duty of the city manager to see that the rules and
regulations are complied with and it is his duty to see that order is
maintained and to protect and promote the best interests of the cemetery. To
that end, he is authorized to make temporary additional rules which may be
needed, from time to time, to meet emergencies which are not covered by these
rules and regulations.
      (13)   Special cases may arise in which the literal enforcement of a rule
may impose unnecessary hardship. The city manager, therefore, is given the
necessary powers to make exceptions, suspensions, or modifications of any of
these rules and regulations, without notice, when in the judgment of the city
manager such action appears necessary; and such temporary exception, suspension
or modification shall in no way be construed as affecting the general
application of such rules and regulations.
   (B)   Enforcement of Rules. The city is hereby empowered to enforce all
rules and regulations and to exclude from the cemetery any person violating the
same. The city shall have charge of the grounds and buildings, including the
conduct of funerals, traffic, employees, plot owners and visitors and at all
times shall have supervision and control of all persons in the cemetery.
(Ord. 2015-03, passed 4-14-2015)
§ 8-3-4 CEMETERY LOTS.
   (A)   Lots and Lot Owners. The following provisions are applicable to lots
and lot owners:
      (1)   Persons desiring to purchase lots should visit the cemetery where
the management will aid them in making a selection. Payment for lots is to be
made at city clerk’s office and a deed to lot will be issued upon receipt of
payment. A copy of the prices in effect for lot spaces is kept in the city
clerk’s office. Prices are subject to change by the city without notice.
      (2)   Lots of various sizes are available in the cemetery and hence such
lots will not be subdivided.
      (3)   No lot shall be used for any other purpose than for the burial of
the human dead.
      (4)   No easement or right of interment is granted to any plot owner in
any road, drive, alley or walk within the cemetery, but such road, drive, alley
or walk may be used as a means of access to the cemetery or buildings, as long
as the city manager devotes it to that purpose.
      (5)   The right to enlarge, reduce, replat or change the boundaries or
grading of the cemetery, or a section or sections, from time to time, including
the right to modify or change the locations of or remove or regrade roads,
drives, or walks, or any part thereof is hereby reserved. The right to lay,
maintain and operate, or alter or change pipelines or gutters for sprinkling
systems or drainage is also expressly reserved, as well as is the right to use
cemetery property not sold to individual plot owners for cemetery purposes,
including interment of the dead, or for anything necessary, incidental or
convenient thereto. The city reserves to itself and to those lawfully entitled
thereto a perpetual right of ingress and egress over plots for the purpose of
passing to and from other plots.
      (6)   Descriptions of lots will be in accordance with the cemetery plats
which are kept on file in the city clerk’s office.
      (7)   The city will take all reasonable precautions to protect lot owners
and the property rights of plot owners within the cemetery from loss or damage;
but the cemetery distinctly disclaims all responsibility for loss or damage
from causes beyond its reasonable control, and especially from strikers,
malicious mischief makers, explosions, unavoidable accidents, invasions,
insurrections, riots, or order of any military or civil authority, whether the
damage be direct or collateral, other than as herein provided.
      (8)   It is the duty of the plot owner to notify the city of any change
in his post office address.
      (9)   The instrument of conveyance of these rules and regulations and any
amendments thereto constitute the sole agreement between the city and the plot
owner. The statement of any employee or agent, unless confirmed in writing by
the city, shall in no way bind the cemetery.
      (10)   The city council shall have the power to limit the placement of a
community mausoleum for vaults and crypts for interments in restricted areas.
      (11)   No private mausoleum shall be allowed after May 1, 1985.
      (12)   A crypt or concrete vault is allowed only with approval of the
city manager and subject to subsection
8-3-5(B) and section
8-3-6 of this chapter.
   (B)   Care of Lots.
      (1)   The general care of the cemetery is assumed by the city.
      (2)   The general care assumed by the city shall in no case mean the
maintenance, repair or replacement of any memorial, tomb, or mausoleum placed
or erected upon lots; nor the doing of any special or unusual work in the
cemetery, including the work caused by the impoverishment of the soil; nor does
it mean the reconstruction of any marble or granite work or any section or
plot, or any portion or portions thereof in the cemetery, caused by the
elements, an act of God, common enemy, thieves, vandals, strikers, malicious
mischief makers, explosions, unavoidable accidents, invasions, insurrections,
riots, or by the order of any military or civil authority, whether the damage
be direct or collateral, other than as herein provided.
      (3)   Lot owners desiring additional care of their lots may arrange for
such care through private contract.
      (4)   The money received for perpetual care shall be held in trust and
invested as provided by law. The city reserves the right, however, either to
handle all investments itself, or to deposit the funds with any person,
company, or corporation qualified to act as trustee for such funds.
      (5)   Concrete walkways will not be allowed between lots.
      (6)   Foundations for grave memorials must be of concrete not less than
five inches (5") deep and extend no less than six inches (6") around the
circumference of the memorial. Foundation requirements shall pertain to all
memorials, including double stones and family monuments and burial vaults that
extend above the surface of the surrounding terrain. Foundations must be level
with surrounding terrain:
         (a)   Grave memorials and foundations will not be installed until
proper location has been verified by the city manager or his representative;
and
         (b)   Each memorial, regardless of size, shall be subject to a setting
permit fee as established by the city’s fee schedule. The fee shall be paid to
the city clerk prior to installation of the memorial.
      (7)   No plot or lot shall be enclosed in any type of ground marker,
curbing or fencing.
   (C)   Descent of Title. The laws of the state govern the descent of title to
cemetery lots as well as other matters pertaining to assignment, conveyance
devices, trust deeds and inalienability. The city will assist any lot owner who
desires information or advice on questions pertaining to his lot.
§ 8-3-5 INTERMENTS.
   (A)   Application for Interment Permit. An application form as established
by the city, and on file in the office of the city clerk, shall be used to
secure an interment permit for interment within any cemetery operated by the
city. All applications must be submitted with a statement signed by family or
friends requesting interment that all fees have been explained and understood
by all parties.
   (B)   General Provisions. The following provisions are applicable to
interments:
      (1)   The cemetery will be open to the public from sunrise to sunset.
      (2)   Where immediate burial is required by laws of the state or under
the rules and regulations of the state board of health, interments may be made
on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays, but an additional fee will be added to the
regular interment charge, otherwise, interments will be permitted only Monday
through Friday.
      (3)   All funerals, on entering the cemetery, shall be under the charge
of city personnel.
      (4)   Once a casket containing a body is within the confines of the
cemetery, no funeral director nor his embalmer, assistant, employee, or agent,
shall be permitted to open the casket or to touch the body without the consent
of the legal representative of the deceased or an order signed by a court of
competent jurisdiction.
      (5)   Funeral directors, upon arrival at the cemetery, must present the
necessary burial permit from the local health office.
      (6)   All orders for interments in lots must be signed by the owner of
the lot or his legal representative. However, when this is impossible because
such person is absent from the city, telegraphic permission will be accepted in
lieu thereof.
      (7)   Lot owners shall not allow interments in their lots in return for
remuneration of any kind.
      (8)   No interment of two (2) or more bodies shall be made in one grave
except in the case of mother and child or two (2) infants in one casket.
      (9)   When an interment is to be made in a lot, the location of such
interment shall be designated by the lot owner. Should the lot owner fail or
neglect to make such designation, the city reserves the right to make the
interment in a location designated by the city manager.
      (10)   The employees of the city are the only persons who will be
permitted to open graves, with the following exceptions:
         (a)   When the cemetery is directed to make a disinterment by the
order of a court of competent jurisdiction and a certified copy of such order
has been filed with the city; or
         (b)   When the district judge directs the disinterment for the purpose
of holding an inquest and has filed with the city his signed authorization to
release the body to himself and his lawful agents. In such case the
disinterment must be made by his lawful agents. City employees will not be
permitted to assist his agents.
      (11)   All charges for interment or services in connection therewith
shall be paid to the city which will issue a receipt therefor upon request. A
fee as set by the city shall be charged for each adult interment and for each
child interment.
      (12)   Arrangements for the payment of any and all indebtedness due the
city must be made before interment will be made.
      (13)   The right is reserved by the city to insist upon at least twenty-
four (24) hours’ notice prior to any interment and at least one week’s notice
prior to any disinterment or removal.
      (14)   All interments, disinterments, and removals must be made at the
time, and in the manner and upon the charges fixed by the city council.
      (15)   Besides being subject to these rules and regulations, all
interments, and disinterments and removals are made subject to the orders and
laws of the properly constituted public authorities.
      (16)   The city will not be responsible for any order given by telephone
or for any mistake occurring from the want of precise and proper instructions
as to the particular space, size of grave, and location in a plot, where
interment is desired.
      (17)   The city will not be liable for the interment permit nor for the
identity of the person sought to be interred.
      (18)   All interments, other than cremated remains, shall be placed in an
outer receptacle which must consist of steel, concrete, fiberglass or other
nonperishable materials of sufficient rigidity to resist pressures that are
applied as a result of ground burial.
(Ord. 1995-08, passed 9-5-1995)
§ 8-3-6 PLANTS AND SHRUBS.
   (A)   Permission from City Required. There shall be no individual beds of
shrubbery or flowers allowed on the grounds except by special permission of the
city. Application for the same should be accompanied by a scaled sketch of the
proposed planting indicating the position and names of the plants and shrubs
suggested.
   (B)   City Authority to Remove. The city shall have authority to remove all
floral designs, flowers, weeds, trees, shrubs, plants, or herbage of any kind
from the cemetery as soon as, in the judgment of the city personnel, they
become unsightly, dangerous, detrimental, or diseased, or when they do not
conform to the standards maintained or as heretofore set forth in the rules and
regulations.
   (C)   Nonliability of City.
      (1)   The city shall not be liable for floral pieces, baskets, or frames
in which, or to which, such floral pieces are attached beyond the acceptance of
such floral pieces for cemetery services held in the cemetery.
      (2)   The city shall not be responsible for frozen plants or herbage of
any kind or for plantings damaged by the elements, thieves, or by other causes
beyond its control.
   (D)   Resale of Lot by Owner; Notice to City. The owner shall notify the
city clerk’s office any time his lot is resold.
   (E)   City Consent for Removal. The city reserves the right to prevent the
removal of any flowers, floral designs, trees, shrubs, plants, or herbage of
any kind unless the city gives consent.

§ 8-4-1 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AIRCRAFT. Pertains to all aircraft including, but not limited to, airplanes,
seaplanes, helicopters, ultralight aircraft, motorized hang gliders, hot air
balloons, any nonpowered flight devices or any other flight equipment.
   BEACH or SWIMMING AREA. Designated areas which include the actual sand beach
and adjoining land area and facilities, as well as the adjacent waters used for
bathing, swimming and wading.
   BUOY. An anchored marker for marking a position on the water, or a hazard,
shoal or mooring, or any other prohibitive activity area.
   CAMPING. Utilization of any piece of equipment for sleeping in or upon
including, but not limited to, a sleeping bag, hammock, station wagon, car,
van, motor home, bus, trailer, tent, tarp, truck, house vehicle, or pickup
camper for the purpose of occupying a portion of public lands for temporary
outdoor living.
   CAMPSITE. Each small section of the camping area that contains a single fire
ring.
   CHANDLER AND BELL COW LAKES. The waters, lands and properties owned or
controlled by the Chandler municipal authority or city of Chandler.
   CHIEF OF POLICE. That person designated by the city manager to be
responsible for the supervision of law enforcement activities which include the
lakes.
   CLASS A VESSEL. A vessel which is less than sixteen feet (16') in length.
   CLASS 1 VESSEL. A vessel which is sixteen feet (16') or longer and less than
twenty-six feet (26') in length.
   CLASS 2 VESSEL. A vessel which is twenty-six feet (26') or longer and less
than forty feet (40') in length.
   CLASS 3 VESSEL. A vessel which is forty feet (40') or longer in length.
   CLOSED ZONE. Any water or land area wherein the presence or operation of all
watercraft or other use is prohibited and marked by appropriate means in
accordance with the uniform waterway marking system or other means.
   DESIGNATED AREAS. Any location, place, site, region, facility, zone, or
space identified as such by the city manager or a designee.
   DOCK. That part of a structure which may be used for the temporary mooring
of watercraft.
   FACILITY. Includes all or any part of structures, equipment or other real or
personal property or interest therein, and the provisions of the facilities.
   FIRE CHIEF. That person designated by the city manager as the chief of the
Chandler fire department which includes jurisdiction of the lakes.
   HORSEPOWER. The horsepower rating published by the manufacturer for the
power unit involved.
   JET SKI DEVICE. A fuel powered outboard or inboard class A motorboat as
defined in 63 O.S. § 4002, which uses an internal combustion engine powering a
water jet pump as its primary source of propulsion.
   JUVENILE. Any person who has not attained their eighteenth birthday.
   LAKE MANAGEMENT AREA. The approximate two thousand two hundred fifty (2,250)
acres of Bell Cow Lake lands owned by the Chandler municipal authority and the
approximate five hundred (500) acres of Chandler Lake land owned by the city.
   LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER. The person(s) designated by the chief of police to
enforce the laws, rules, and regulations at the lakes and to issue citations or
effectuate arrests for violations of game, fishing, boating and other
violations of city ordinances.
   LENGTH OF BOAT. Refers to the overall length of the hull, extending from end
to end over the deck, excluding sheer, measured in a straight line from the
foremost part of a vessel and parallel to the centerline. Bow sprits, bumpkins,
rudders, outboard motor brackets and similar fittings or attachments are not
included in the measurement. Length shall be stated in feet and inches. Class A
boats are under sixteen feet (16'). Class 1 boats are between sixteen (16) and
twenty-six feet (26'). Class 2 boats are between twenty-six (26) and forty feet
(40'). Class 3 boats are above forty feet (40'). Class 2 and 3 boats are
prohibited on city lakes.
   MINOR. Any person over sixteen (16) years of age but under eighteen (18)
years of age.
   MOTORBOAT. Any vessel propelled by machinery, whether or not such machinery
is the principal source of propulsion.
   OPERATE. To navigate or otherwise use a motorboat or a vessel.
   OPERATOR. The person who operates, has actual physical control, or has
charge of the navigation or use of a vessel.
   PERMIT. Any written license or letter of consent issued by or under the
authority of the city manager or a designee of the city manager, permitting the
performance of a specific act or acts.
   PERMITTEE. A person who lawfully possesses a permit.
   PERSONAL FLOTATION DEVICE (PFD). A lifesaving device which has been approved
by the U.S. coast guard.
   PERSONAL WATERCRAFT. A vessel which uses an inboard motor powering a water
jet pump as its primary source of motive power and which is designed to be
operated by a person sitting, standing or kneeling on the vessel, rather than
the conventional manner of sitting or standing inside the vessel, or a vessel
which is similar in appearance and operation to a personal watercraft but which
is powered by an outboard or propeller driven motor, or a vessel less than
sixteen feet (16') in length which travels across the water above or on a
cushion of air provided by engines, propellers or other means of propulsion.
   PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR. That person designated by the city manager to be
responsible for the supervision of building and maintenance operations at the
lakes.
   REPORTABLE BOATING ACCIDENT. An accident, collision or other casualty
involving a vessel which results in loss of life, injury sufficient to require
first aid or medical attention, or actual physical damage to property in excess
of five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   SCUBA. Divers equipped with self-contained underwater breathing apparatus.
   TRAIL. Any designated path or trail for persons riding on horseback, walking
or hiking.
   UNDER WAY. The movement of a vessel whether by mechanical or nonmechanical
means which is other than incidental to the force of wind, waves or current.
   VESSEL. Every description of watercraft, other than a seaplane on the water,
used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on water.
   WAKE. The track of waves left by a vessel or other object moving through the
water, and such waves are greater than the natural waves in the immediate area
of the vessel, or are cresting and showing white water, or may cause injury or
damage to any person or property.
   WATERCRAFT. Any vessel used or capable of being used as a means of
transportation on water, including, but not limited to, powerboats, cruisers,
houseboats, sailboats, rowboats, canoes, kayaks, jet skis and any other such
equipment.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4-2 LAKE USE PERMITS.
   (A)   Minimum Age. No permit required by the provisions of this chapter
shall be issued to any person under the age of sixteen (16) years. Children
under age sixteen (16) can fish for free if they are in the company of a
permittee.
   (B)   Proration or Refund Disallowed. No fee required by this section shall
be prorated and no fee once paid shall be refunded due to inclement weather
conditions, except advance payments on pavilion rentals.
   (C)   Issuance. All boat permits required by the provisions of this chapter
shall be issued by the city clerk or such other persons as may be designated by
the city council or the city manager.
   (D)   Transfer. No permit issued under the provisions of this chapter shall
be transferable to any other person.
   (E)   Expiration. Annual permits issued under the provisions of this chapter
shall expire on December 31 following its date of issuance. Daily permits shall
expire twenty-four (24) hours from time of issue.
   (F)   Possession, Display. Each permittee with a daily boat permit issued
under the provisions of this chapter shall carry a current permit upon their
person while on the lake and produce it upon demand of any city employee
authorized to require the same.
   (G)   Boat Tag. The annual boat permit shall be designated by proper tag on
each side near the stern end of the boat, which must be plainly visible for a
distance of at least one hundred feet (100') from said boat. Such tag shall be
furnished with the permit by the city.
   (H)   Revocation of Permit. Any permit issued under the provisions of this
chapter may be revoked for the violation by the permittee of any applicable
provision of state law, this code or city ordinance, rule or regulation.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994; Ord. 1995-11, passed 12-5-1995)
§ 8-4-3 VEHICULAR TRAFFIC LAWS.
   (A)   City and State Traffic Law Supplement. These rules are in addition to
and supplement the city and state traffic laws which are in force and which are
incorporated herein and made a part hereof.
   (B)   Parking.
      (1)   General Regulations. Vehicles shall not be left unattended in the
event of the owner’s arrest, nor be parked in violation of posted restrictions,
or in such a manner as to obstruct or impede normal or emergency traffic
movement or the parking of other vehicles, nor create a safety hazard or
endanger any persons, facility or environmental feature. Vehicles so parked are
subject to removal and impoundment at the owner’s expense.
      (2)   Time Limits. Parking any vehicle in any designated parking lot or
parking area for a period of time in excess of twenty-four (24) hours or past
the posted closing time without obtaining prior written permission is
prohibited, except vehicles registered to campers covered by camping fees.
      (3)   Parking Unlawfully in Camping Area. Motor vehicles which are found
parked in a campground area and are not registered to a campsite with a valid
and current camping permit plainly displayed on the motor vehicle shall be
considered unlawfully parked.
   (C)   Traffic Routes. No person shall operate any vehicle or ride any
bicycle within any area except on such roads, streets, driveways, trails, paths
and other such thoroughfares which are designated or posted for such purposes.
No person shall drive around any barrier or gate which is across a road or
trail or drive a motor vehicle or bicycle upon such barricaded or closed
thoroughfare. Bicycles and vehicles of any type are prohibited on horse trails.
There shall be no parking of vehicles or trailers on any unpaved areas not
designated for parking.
   (D)   Operator’s State Vehicle License. All vehicles and operators must
possess a valid state motor vehicle license.
   (E)   Vehicle Operation. Vehicles shall be operated only in accordance with
posted restrictions and regulations and applicable federal, state and city
laws.
   (F)   Noise or Smoke. In no area shall any person operate any motor vehicle
that is producing an unusual amount of noise or smoke or in such a way as to
create unnecessary noise or smoke from the motor vehicle.
   (G)   Unnecessary Operation. No person shall operate any motor vehicle
within any area except for necessary, direct transportation to or from his
campsite or to and from a campsite or facility for which permission has been
granted.
   (H)   Right-of-Way. The operator of a motor vehicle, bicycle or horse shall
grant the right-of-way to all pedestrian crossings, streets, lanes or roads
within any area.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994; Ord. 1995-11, passed 12-5-1995)
§ 8-4-4 AIRCRAFT.
   (A)   Aircraft Operation. The operation of aircraft on or within the
immediate airspace, that is less than five hundred feet (500') AGL, is
prohibited. This provision shall not be applicable to aircraft engaged on
official business of federal, state or local governments, law enforcement
agencies or aircraft used in emergency rescue.
   (B)   Careless, Negligent or Reckless Operation. No person shall operate any
aircraft while on or above waters or lands of the lakes in a careless,
negligent or reckless manner so as to endanger any person or property.
   (C)   Federal Aviation Rules. This section bestows no authority to deviate
from rules and regulations, prescribed standards of the appropriate state
aeronautical agency or the federal aviation administration including, but not
limited to, regulations and standards concerning pilot certifications or
ratings and airspace requirements.
   (D)   Air Delivery. The air delivery of any person, material or equipment by
parachute, helicopter or other means onto lands and waters of the lakes without
written permission is prohibited except in extreme emergencies threatening
human life.
   (E)   Water Landing. Aircraft utilized for water landing and takeoff are
prohibited at the lakes.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994; Ord. 1995-11, passed 12-5-1995)
§ 8-4-5 SWIMMING AND PICNICKING.
   (A)   Swimming Areas. Swimming in the lakes will only be allowed in those
areas designated as swimming areas. Such areas will be marked by buoy line, and
swimming will only be allowed on the beach side of the buoys. Swimming on the
lakeside of the buoys is prohibited.
   (B)   Entering Water from Boat. Swimming from a boat or entering the water
from a boat, except for the purpose of skiing, sailing, windsurfing or scuba
diving, is prohibited.
   (C)   Scuba Diving. Scuba diving is permitted in designated areas only.
   (D)   Nudity. No person shall publicly appear nude or disrobe while in any
area of the lakes except in authorized areas of buildings set aside for that
purpose.
   (E)   Diving. Diving or jumping from bridges, land or other structures which
cross or are adjacent to the lakes is prohibited.
   (F)   Swimmer’s Risk. All swimming shall be at the swimmer’s own risk.
   (G)   Children Swimming. All children age twelve (12) years and younger must
be accompanied by an adult before entering the swimming area. A regulation life
preserver must be worn by children eight (8) years old and younger.
   (H)   Animals in Swimming Areas. No animals will be allowed in the
designated swimming area.
   (I)   Picnic Areas. Picnicking is allowed only in those areas so designated
by the posting of appropriate signs.
   (J)   Day Use. Day use of a park area shall be from seven o’clock (7:00)
A.M. until ten o’clock (10:00) P.M., unless otherwise posted.
   (K)   Cleanliness of Picnic Area. Picnickers shall keep their sites free of
trash and litter during the period of occupancy, shall remove all personal
equipment and clean their site upon departure.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994; Ord. 1995-11, passed 12-5-1995)
§ 8-4-6 CAMPING.
   (A)   Camping Area. Camping is allowed in designated areas only.
   (B)   Camping Permit. No person shall camp within the lake lands unless such
person possesses a current and valid camping permit. Persons renting a pavilion
and camping near to it shall pay the daily pavilion rate plus the current
primitive camp rate for each individual vehicle or tent.
   (C)   Campsites. Camping at one or more campsites at the lakes is limited to
a period no longer than fourteen (14) consecutive days.
   (D)   Permanent Camping Facilities. The installation of permanent camping
facilities is prohibited. The digging or leveling of any ground or construction
of any structure is prohibited. This does not prohibit the erection of a tent
in designated areas.
   (E)   Quiet Hours. Quiet hours will be enforced from ten o’clock (10:00)
P.M. until six o’clock (6:00) A.M. Loud noises that may disturb the peace are
prohibited during these hours. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a
motorcycle, motorbike, television, boom box, radio, or phonographic equipment
after ten o’clock (10:00) P.M. within the camping facilities. It shall be
unlawful for any person to disturb other persons in the camping areas by any
loud or unusual noise, loud language or by any other behavior which causes
disturbance.
   (F)   Juvenile Campers. No person who is a juvenile shall camp in any area
of the lakes except when accompanied by a parent or guardian.
   (G)   Camping Unit Limits. Camping will be limited to no more than two (2)
camping units per campsite. Camping units include tents, lean-tos, teepees, pop
up trailers, travel trailers, fifth wheel trailers and motor homes.
   (H)   Dogs. It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or permit a dog to
be within city property unless such dog is on a leash at all times; provided
however, that dogs used to hunt waterfowl or to accompany trail riders and
which are under the immediate voice control of their handlers shall be exempt
from the leash requirement.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994; Ord. 1995-11, passed 12-5-1995; Ord. 1999-04,
passed 7-6-1999)
§ 8-4-7 HUNTING, FISHING AND TRAPPING.
   (A)   Federal, State and Local Laws. All federal, state and local laws
governing hunting or fishing apply on the lakes lands and waters except as
these laws may be modified by the city for purposes of regulating fishing and
wildlife.
   (B)   Trotlines, Juglines, Throwlines, Limblines and Yo-Yos.
      (1)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
         JUGLINE. A vertical line with hooks suspended from a nonmetallic or
nonglass device, drifting free or anchored, left unattended for a means of
taking fish.
         LIMBLINE. A line with hooks attached to a limb, branch or other
natural object left unattended for the means of taking fish.
         THROWLINE. A line attached at one end and weighted at the other with
hooks along its length left unattended for the means of taking fish.
         TROTLINE. A line with hooks placed along its length placed in the
water attached at each end and left unattended for a means of taking fish.
         YO-YO. A line with hooks attached to a self-activating retracting
device left unattended for the means of taking fish.
      (2)   Prohibition. Fishing by trotline, jugline, throwline, limbline or
yo-yo is prohibited in all areas of the lakes.
   (C)   Fishing Areas. No person shall at any time engage in fishing in any
swimming beach waters or in any area of the lakes posted prohibiting fishing.
   (D)   Prohibited Area. No fishing shall be permitted within one hundred feet
(100') of the intake tower or any water supply conduit, or upon any culture
pond now established or which may hereafter be established, by the city.
   (E)   Waist Flotation Device. The waist flotation device commonly known as a
“belly boat” shall be permitted for use when fishing on the lakes except when
the use of such device interferes with the free and proper use of navigable
waters or unnecessarily endangers life or limb of the occupant.
   (F)   Trapping. No person shall trap animals within any area of the lakes.
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any net or trap for fishing in the
lakes.
   (G)   Hunting. Hunting is limited to deer and duck during specified seasons
and only in areas as set from year to year.
   (H)   Restricted Fishing in Ski Areas. No fishing will be permitted in
designated ski areas during the hours water skiing is permitted as defined in
subsection
8-4A-22 (C) of this chapter. Fishing is allowed near the dam or shoreline in
ski areas, as long as a boat does not go out further than fifty feet (50') from
the dam or shoreline in ski areas, or as prohibited in subsection (D) of this
section.
   (I)   Bag Limits. Size and bag limits shall be the same size and bag limit
as set forth by state laws and regulations, except as may be modified by the
city to manage and encourage trophy bass fishing. Permittees are responsible to
know the current slot limits for various species of fish.
   (J)   Lures, Baits Restricted. Only artificial lures and live bait, such as
worms, minnows or crawfish or fresh bait, such as fresh and unspoiled or
untainted shrimp, liver, beef, or other fresh meats which would be fit for
human consumption, may be used for fishing bait in the lakes.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4-8 SANITATION.
   (A)   Trash Disposition. No person shall leave, place or dispose of in any
manner: garbage; peelings of vegetables or fruit; waste; refuse; rubbish;
ashes; cans; bottles; wire; paper; cartons; boxes; motor vehicle, bicycle or
wagon parts; furniture; glass; oils; sewage; anything of an unsightly or
unsanitary nature under or upon the lands and waters of the lakes. Trash is to
be placed in receptacles designated for that purpose.
   (B)   Dumping Trash. No person shall bring into the lakes or lake property
any household or commercial garbage, trash, rubbish, debris, dead animals or
litter of any kind for disposal or dumping.
   (C)   Contaminant Dumping. Spilling, pumping or discharge of contaminants,
pollutants or other wastes including, but not limited to, human or animal
waste, petroleum, industrial and commercial products and byproducts on the
lands or waters of the lakes is prohibited.
   (D)   Littering. Campers, picnickers and all other persons using the areas
and facilities of the lakes shall keep their sites free of trash and litter
during the period of occupancy, and shall remove all personal equipment and
clean their sites upon departure.
   (E)   Sewage Discharge. The discharge or placing of sewage, galley waste,
garbage, refuse or pollutants onto the waters and lands of the lakes is
prohibited.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4-9 FIRES.
   (A)   Use of Fires. No person shall kindle, build, maintain or use a fire
other than in places provided or designated for such purposes.
   (B)   Improper Disposal of Burning Material. Improper disposal of lighted
materials, matches or other burning material is prohibited.
   (C)   Unattended Fires. Fires shall not be left unattended and must be
completely extinguished prior to departure.
   (D)   Fuels. Gasoline and other fuels, except that which is contained in
storage tanks of vehicles, watercraft, camping equipment or hand portable
containers designed for such purpose, shall not be carried onto or stored at
the lakes without written permission from the fire chief or his designee.
   (E)   Cutting Wood. Tree branches lying on the ground may be picked up and
cut for firewood to be used at a campsite only. Live trees or standing trees
that are dead shall not be cut nor shall stripping dead branches out of live or
dead trees be allowed. Cutting and removing of wood from lake property is
prohibited. No wood shall be cut from trees standing in the waters of the
lakes.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
ARTICLE A. WATERCRAFT
§ 8-4A-1 ADOPTION OF STATE BOAT AND WATER CODES.
   The provisions of the Oklahoma vessel and motor registration act, 63 O.S. §§
4001 et seq., and the provisions of the Oklahoma vessel and motor excise tax
act, 63 O.S. §§ 4101 et seq., and the provisions of the Oklahoma boating safety
regulation act, 63 O.S. §§ 4200 et seq., and all rules and regulations
promulgated in furtherance thereof are hereby adopted and incorporated herein
by reference, and are enforceable by the city within the city limits as fully
as if set forth at length herein.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-2 OPERATION OF WATERCRAFT.
   Watercraft or other vessels may be operated on the lakes, except in
prohibited or restricted areas, in accordance with posted restrictions,
including buoys, signs or markers as regulated by enforcement personnel of the
lakes. Speed limits at night or under adverse weather conditions shall not
exceed fifteen (15) knots.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-3 REGISTRATION; LICENSING; ANNUAL TAX DECAL.
   (A)   Registration Requirements. All watercraft operated on the waters of
the lakes shall be numbered in accordance with the state statutes and
regulations. Letters and numbers shall be three inches (3") to four inches (4")
in height with one-half inch (1/2") to three-fourths inch (3/4") strokes, of
contrasting color to the boat. Letters and numbers must be spaced one-half inch
(1/2") to three-fourths inch (3/4") and within an area of thirty inches (30")
along each side of the bow. The numbers shall be maintained in a legible
condition and easily read at a distance of one hundred feet (100').
   (B)   Current Registration on Watercraft. All watercraft shall possess and
maintain on board a current registration whenever the watercraft is operated on
the lakes, except: 1) rental watercraft may keep a rental agreement in lieu of
registration; 2) in the case of new watercraft or transfer of ownership of a
watercraft, a temporary registration or photocopied registration will be
acceptable.
   (C)   Annual Tax Decal. All watercraft shall possess and display the annual
tax decal along with the registration numbers on the watercraft. The annual tax
decal shall be due on July 1 each year and shall become delinquent on August 1
thereafter.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-4 WATERCRAFT CAPACITY.
   (A)   Capacity Plate Requirements. All watercraft less than twenty feet
(20') in length, manufactured, or imported into this state after July 1, 1974,
designed to carry two (2) or more persons, and propelled by machinery as its
principal source of power shall be in compliance with United States coast guard
safety standards and horsepower limits of the motor and have permanently
affixed a capacity plate. The capacity plate shall bear the following
information:
      (1)   The total weight of persons, motor, gear and other articles placed
aboard which the vessel is capable of carrying with safety under normal
conditions.
      (2)   The recommended number of persons commensurate with the weight
capacity of the watercraft and the presumed weight in pounds of each such
person, not to be presumed to be less than one hundred fifty (150) pounds.
      (3)   The maximum horsepower limits of the outboard motor within which
the vessel is designed to and intended to accommodate.
   (B)   Capacity Limits. No person shall use or operate a watercraft in excess
of the loading or horsepower limits as established by the United States coast
guard safety standards on the capacity plate, and any violation thereof is
prima facie evidence of reckless operation.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-5 EQUIPMENT AND CONDITION OF VESSEL.
   (A)   Fire Extinguishers. Every vessel using flammable liquid as fuel shall
be equipped with such number, size, and type of United States coast guard
approved fire extinguisher as prescribed in the rules of the state department
of public safety. Such extinguisher shall be capable of promptly and
effectively extinguishing burning fuel. Fire extinguishers shall be at all
times kept in condition for immediate and effective use and shall be so placed
and secured to the vessel as to be readily accessible.
   (B)   Ventilation. Every vessel, except open vessels, using any liquid as
fuel shall be provided with such means as may be prescribed by the United
States coast guard for properly and efficiently ventilating the bilges of the
motor and fuel tank compartments so as to remove any explosive or inflammable
gases.
   (C)   Mufflers. No person shall operate upon the waters of the lakes any
vessel or motor which is not equipped with a muffler, underwater exhaust, or
other device capable of adequately muffling the sound of the motor’s exhaust.
ADEQUATE MUFFLING, as used herein, shall mean that the motor’s exhaust is at
all times muffled or suppressed so as not to create excessive or unusual noise
which would annoy the peace and tranquility of persons of ordinary senses. The
use of cutouts, removal of mufflers or muffler baffles, cutting or punching of
holes in mufflers or otherwise modifying the original muffler or muffling
system installed by the manufacturer or any subsequent muffler or muffling
system so as to increase or modify the noise level is prohibited. This
subsection shall not apply to vessels in the act of participating in a
sanctioned event.
   (D)   Flame Arresters. Every vessel shall have the carburetor or carburetors
of every motor therein, except outboard motors, using any liquid as fuel,
equipped with a United States coast guard or UL or SAE approved backfire flame
arrestor or other appropriate attachment, as prescribed by the rules of the
state department of public safety.
   (E)   Whistle and Horn. Every vessel shall be provided with an efficient
whistle or other sound producing mechanical appliance; provided however, no
vessel, except for emergency and law enforcement vessels, shall be equipped
with a siren.
   (F)   Length Limit. All watercraft will be limited to a length not to exceed
twenty-six feet (26') and horsepower limits set by manufacturer’s rating of the
watercraft.
   (G)   Lighting. Every vessel in all weather between the hours from sunset to
sunrise shall carry and exhibit the lights prescribed by the United States
coast guard when under way, including, but not limited to, the following:
      (1)   Every vessel of classes A and 1 shall carry:
         (a)   A bright white light aft to show all around the horizon; and
         (b)   A combined lantern in the forepart of the vessel and lower than
the white light aft, showing green to starboard and red to port.
      (2)   Vessels of all classes when propelled by sail alone shall carry,
ready at hand, a lantern or flashlight showing a white light which shall be
exhibited in sufficient time to avert collision.
      (3)   When propelled by sail and motor, any vessel shall carry the lights
required by this section for a vessel propelled by motor only.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994; Ord. 2006-03, passed 8-7-2006)
§ 8-4A-6 RECKLESS OPERATION; OPERATION UNDER INFLUENCE.
   (A)   Reckless or Negligent Operation. No person shall operate or give
permission to operate any vessel or manipulate or give permission to manipulate
any parasails, waterskis, surfboard, or similar device in a reckless or
negligent manner so as to endanger the life or property of any person.
   (B)   Operation Under Influence. No person shall operate or give permission
to operate any vessel on any waters of this state, except privately owned
waters, while the operator is under the influence of alcohol or any substance
included in the uniform controlled dangerous substances act (63 O.S. §§ 2-101
et seq.).
   (C)   Approach of Authorized Emergency Vessel. Upon the immediate approach
of an authorized emergency vessel making use of an audible or a visual signal
or a combination thereof, the operator of every other vessel shall immediately
stop his or her vessel whenever or wherever practical or otherwise yield the
right-of-way until such authorized emergency vessel has passed, except when
otherwise directed by a duly authorized peace officer of this state.
   (D)   Overloading Vessel. No person shall overload or give permission to
overload a vessel with persons or gear so as to exceed the posted capacity
plate or to exceed United States coast guard standards.
   (E)   Violation, Negligent Act. Any violation of the provisions of this
section shall constitute a negligent act in the operation of the vessel or
motor or parasails.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-7 CARE AND PRUDENT SPEED.
   (A)   Prudent Speed.
      (1)   Any person who operates or gives permission to operate a vessel on
any waters of the lakes shall operate the same at a careful and prudent speed
not greater than nor less than is reasonable or proper, having due regard to
other vessels, waterskiers, swimmers, sanctioned events, restrictive and
informational markers or buoys, existing wind conditions, waves, wakes or other
weather conditions, then existing.
      (2)   No person shall operate a watercraft on the waters of the lakes at
a speed greater or less than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions
then existing, considering among other things the condition or type of the
watercraft, weather, visibility, presence of other watercraft or vessels,
presence of buoys or of other obstructions, proximity to the shoreline or
restricted areas, and depth of water.
   (B)   Wake Zone. No person shall operate or give permission to operate a
vessel in a wake zone at a speed which shows no regard for the existence of
actual or potential hazards and obstacles, or in such a manner as to endanger
the life, limb or property of any other person, or in such a manner as to
create a wake. For the purpose of this title, NO WAKE ZONE means any area
posted with buoys or within one hundred fifty feet (150') of any boat ramp,
dock, pier, or anchored or moored vessel.
   (C)   Violation, Careless Act. Any violation of the provisions of this
section shall constitute a careless act in the operation of the vessel.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-8 RIDING IN OR ON WATERCRAFT.
   (A)   Riding and Standing Restrictions. No person shall sit or ride on the
sides of a vessel, a covered bow or the back of any seat of a vessel, or stand
in a vessel while under way at any speed greater than idle or trolling speed;
provided however, the operator of such vessel may stand if said vessel is
specifically designed to be operated from a standing position.
   (B)   Operator Responsibility. No operator shall allow any person to occupy
the front or back deck of any vessel while under way at any speed greater than
idle or trolling speed, nor any structure above the main deck without adequate
safety rails or lines so constructed as to prevent such person from slipping or
falling overboard.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-9 PROCEDURE UPON COLLISION, ACCIDENT OR OTHER CASUALTY.
   (A)   Duties of Operator.
      (1)   The operator and/or passenger of a vessel involved in a collision,
accident, or other casualty shall render to other persons involved in the
collision, accident, or other casualty reasonable assistance as may be
necessary and practicable and shall immediately, by the quickest means of
communication, give notice of such accident to the local police department if
such accident occurs within a municipality, or to the office of the county
sheriff or nearest state highway patrol headquarters after complying with the
requirements of this section.
      (2)   The operator of a vessel involved in a collision, accident, or
other casualty shall give his name, address, and identification of his vessel,
in writing, to any person injured in the collision, accident, or other casualty
and to the owner of any property damaged in the collision, accident or other
casualty.
   (B)   File Accident Report with State. If a collision, accident, or other
casualty results in death or injury to a person or damage to property in excess
of five hundred dollars ($500.00), the operator of the vessel involved in the
collision, accident, or other casualty shall file with the state department of
public safety a full description of the collision, accident, or other casualty,
and such information as the department may require.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-10 RULES OF RIGHT-OF-WAY.
   (A)   Approaching Head On. When two (2) watercraft are approaching each
other “head on” or nearly so (so as to involve risk of collision) each
watercraft shall bear to the right and pass the other watercraft on its left
side.
   (B)   Approaching at Right Angles. When two (2) boats approach each other
obliquely, or at right angles, the watercraft approaching on the right has the
right-of-way.
   (C)   Overtaking Another Motorcraft. When a motorcraft may overtake another
on either side but shall grant right-of-way to the overtaken boat, the vessel
being overtaken shall hold its course and speed.
   (D)   Sailing Vessel Right-of-Way. When a motorboat and a sailing vessel are
proceeding in such direction as to involve risk of collision, the motorized
vessel shall keep out of the way of the sailing vessel.
   (E)   Passing Watercraft at Anchor. When a watercraft which is under way
passes by a watercraft which is at anchor, the watercraft moving shall maintain
a minimum distance of one hundred fifty feet (150') and exercise due care with
regard to the wake being created.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-11 WATERCRAFT NOT IN USE.
   All watercraft when not in actual use shall be removed from the waters of
the lakes unless temporarily (15 minutes or less) moored at the designated
facilities provided or secured pursuant to section
8-4A-16 of this article.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-12 MOORING FACILITIES.
   The placement of floating or stationary mooring facilities on, adjacent to,
or interfering with, a buoy, channel marker or other navigational aid is
prohibited.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-13 LAUNCHING OR LOADING OF WATERCRAFT.
   No person shall launch or load any watercraft in any area of the lakes
except at those locations so designated.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-14 UNATTENDED WATERCRAFT.
   Leaving any watercraft unattended or outside the designated mooring facility
in violation of posted restriction is prohibited and any watercraft so left may
be impounded.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-15 DRIVERS USING MECHANICAL DIVING OR BREATHING DEVICE.
   (A)   Placing Buoy and Flag at Points of Submergence. Any person diving or
submerging in a body of water with the aid of any mechanical diving or
breathing device or suit shall place a buoy with a flag in the water at or near
the point of submergence or fly a flag from a vessel indicating divers are
present, in the following manner:
      (1)   Either the nationally recognized diver’s flag or alpha flag may be
flown;
      (2)   When flown from a vessel, at least one flag shall be flown not less
than one meter above the highest point of the vessel and shall be visible from
a three hundred sixty (360) degree circle;
      (3)   The buoy, flag or flags shall be in place only while actual diving
operations are in progress;
      (4)   No diving buoys may be closer than three hundred (300) yards to
each other or closer than three hundred (300) yards to any dock, functional
boat ramp or designated swimming area; and
      (5)   The flag or flags shall be in good condition and legible, and the
flag shall be in the extended position so as to be visible to any other vessel.
   (B)   Operating Motorboat in Area of Diver’s Flag. It shall be unlawful for
any person to operate a motor driven boat within one hundred fifty feet (150')
of a buoy except while engaged in the rescue of a person in such area.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-16 WATERCRAFT SECURITY AT NIGHT.
   No operator shall drift, anchor, dock, moor, tie up or beach a watercraft on
lands or waters of the lakes and sleep thereon at night except those watercraft
in association of campers within a designated camping area.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-17 WATERCRAFT USER FEE.
   All watercraft shall display or possess a current lakes user fee permit in
conjunction with the state registration numbers and annual tax decal. Annual
watercraft permits shall be effective for a calendar year.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-18 WATERCRAFT SAFETY REQUIREMENTS.
   All watercraft shall comply with the Oklahoma boating safety act (63 O.S. §§
4200 et seq.).
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-19 FLOTATION DEVICES.
   (A)   Use of Personal Flotation Devices.
      (1)   The operator of a vessel less than twenty-six feet (26') in length,
while under way, shall require each passenger who is twelve (12) years of age
or younger to wear a personal flotation device.
      (2)   Any person operating or manipulating a personal watercraft,
waterskis, a sailboard or a similar device shall wear a personal flotation
device approved and designed for the activity in which the person is engaged.
   (B)   Condition, Size of Devices.
      (1)   Each personal flotation device shall be in good serviceable
condition, of the type prescribed by the United States coast guard and of a
size suitable to the person who is wearing it.
      (2)   A ski belt is not a United States coast guard approved personal
flotation device.
   (C)   Devices Kept on Board.
      (1)   Every vessel shall be required to carry:
         (a)   At least one wearable personal flotation device for each person
on board, so placed as to be readily accessible and of a size suitable to the
person who is or will be wearing it; and
         (b)   At least one type IV (throwable) personal floatation device on
board, so placed as to be readily accessible.
      (2)   All lifesaving devices shall be in good and serviceable condition.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-20 AIRBORNE DEVICE ON WATERCRAFT.
   While being towed by a watercraft or motor vehicle, no person shall have any
airfoil or balloon device in hand or affixed to a person for the purpose of
becoming airborne over the lands or waters of the lakes unless written
permission has first been obtained from the city manager or his designee,
thirty (30) days in advance.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-21 PERSONAL WATERCRAFT.
   (A)   Operation in Designated Area. No person shall operate a boat within
the area of the lakes which has been designated personal watercraft only,
marked as “Jet Skis Only”.
   (B)   Restrictions. In addition to those rules and regulations established
by this chapter and state law concerning the operation of watercraft on the
waters of the lakes, operators of personal watercraft shall be subject to the
following restrictions:
      (1)   A person may not operate or give permission to operate any personal
watercraft in a reckless, negligent or careless manner so as to endanger life,
limb or property of any person including the operator of such watercraft.
      (2)   A person may not operate or give permission to operate a personal
watercraft without a United States coast guard approved lifesaving device (PFD)
of the proper size and type, either a type I, II, III, or V; preferably a type
III with an impact rating of at least thirty-five (35) miles per hour, which
shall be worn while such craft is in operation.
      (3)   A person may not operate or give permission to operate a personal
watercraft within one hundred fifty feet (150') of any person, other vessel,
dock, buoy, bridge, or any other prohibitive structure at a speed greater than
“idle” or slow steerageway speed.
      (4)   A person may not operate or give permission to operate a personal
watercraft as a means for towing a waterskier, surfboard, water tow, or similar
device, unless the watercraft is designed and equipped for such towing by the
manufacturer. The personal watercraft must meet all required state boating laws
for skiing and towing. The owner of a personal watercraft must submit the
vessel for a one time inspection by the chief ranger or his assistant, to
ensure it is designed and equipped by the manufacturer for towing. Upon
approval by the chief ranger or his assistant, a special sticker will be placed
on the vessel to designate it has met the requirements for towing. An
inspection fee will be as fixed by city council resolution.
      (5)   A person may not operate a personal watercraft on the waters of the
lakes, unless it is equipped with a self-circling device, or a lanyard type
engine cutoff switch.
      (6)   A person may not operate a personal watercraft equipped by the
manufacturer with a lanyard type engine cutoff switch, unless the lanyard is
operational and attached to the operator, operator’s clothing, or a personal
flotation device worn by the operator.
      (7)   A person may not operate or give permission to operate a personal
watercraft equipped by the manufacturer with a self-circling device, if the
self-circling device or engine throttle has been altered in any way that would
prohibit the self-circling device from operating in its intended manner.
      (8)   A person may not operate or give permission to operate a personal
watercraft between sunset and sunrise. For the purpose of this section, times
of sunrise and sunset for a given day shall be the same as those officially
designated by the national weather service.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994; Ord. 2001-03, passed 7-3-2001)
§ 8-4A-22 WATERSKIING.
   (A)   Definition. For the purpose of this chapter, the term WATERSKIING
shall mean the activity of being propelled along the water upon devices known
as skis and being at the same time towed by some type of boat and shall include
the use of surfboards, ski bikes, or any other device which may be used to
sustain any person upon the water while being towed by a motorboat.
   (B)   Observation of Towed Person. No person shall operate or give
permission to operate a vessel on any waters of the lakes for towing a person
or persons using parasails or on waterskis, a surfboard, or similar device
unless there is in such vessel a person who is at least eight (8) years old,
and who, in addition to the operator, is in a position to observe the progress
of the person or persons being towed, or unless an efficient wide angle convex
rear view mirror has been installed on such vessel in such manner as to permit
the person operating said vessel to face the direction of travel and be in a
position to observe the progress of the person or persons being towed.
   (C)   Hours. No person shall operate or give permission to operate a vessel
on any waters of the lakes towing a person or persons using parasails or on
waterskis, a surfboard, a sailboard or similar device, nor shall any person
engage in parasailing, waterskiing, surfboarding, sailboarding or similar
activities at any time between the hours of sunset and sunrise or at such time
visibility due to other existing conditions is obscured so as to endanger life
or property.
   (D)   Towing Water Skier. No person shall operate or give permission to
operate or manipulate any vessel, tow rope or other device by which the
direction or location of parasails, waterskis, a surfboard, or similar device
may be affected or controlled in such a way as to cause the parasails,
waterskis, surfboard, or similar device, or any person thereon, to collide with
or strike against any object or person.
   (E)   Attending Waterskier. No person shall operate a vessel on the waters
of the lakes while towing a person on waterskis, a surfboard or similar
activity and leave the skier unattended in the waters in such a manner as to
endanger the skier or unnecessarily interfere with the free and proper use of
the navigable waters by other vessels therein.
   (F)   Towing Skiers, Direction of Travel. All watercraft towing skiers upon
the waters of the lakes shall move generally in a counterclockwise direction.
   (G)   Area Restricted. No person shall engage in waterskiing except in the
area outlined for such activity by the official lake officer employed by the
city.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994; Ord. 1995-11, passed 12-5-1995)
§ 8-4A-23 JET SKIS, SKI BIKES OR SIMILAR DEVICES.
   (A)   Licensing and Registration; Regulations. All jet skis, ski bikes or
similar devices must be registered with the state of Oklahoma and licensed by
the city. All operators of such devices must wear United States coast guard
life preservers at all times, and operators of such equipment must conform to
the water rules, regulations and safety laws, as apply to the operation of
boats on the lakes.
   (B)   Restricted Areas for Jet Skis. No person may operate a jet ski device
on the waters of the lakes except in those areas specifically designated for
such use.
   (C)   Designated Areas. Jet skis, ski bikes or similar devices operated in
areas designated “no wake” shall not exceed fifteen (15) miles per hour.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-24 RENTAL OF PRIVATE BOATS PROHIBITED.
   Owners of private boats of all types shall not be permitted to rent their
boats for use on the lakes or to collect fares or to take donations for the use
of the same.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-25 INEXPERIENCED BOAT OPERATORS.
   Persons inexperienced in boat operation or persons under the age of fifteen
(15) years shall not operate a boat which is engaged in activity skiing upon
the lakes, unless accompanied by an adult experienced in boat operations.
(Ord. 1994-06, passed 11-1-1994)
§ 8-4A-26 ABANDONMENT OF VESSEL; REMOVAL.
