§ 10-1-1 BUILDING CODE ADOPTED.
   A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the Office of
the City Clerk of the City of Chandler, Oklahoma, being marked and designated
as the International Building Code, 2015 edition, including all appendix
chapters as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby
adopted as the Building Code of the City of Chandler, Oklahoma for regulating
and governing the conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and
structures; by providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities
and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures
are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use; and the condemnation of
buildings and structures unfit for human occupancy and use and the demolition
of such structures as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits
and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations,
provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Building Code on file in
the Office of the Chandler City Clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made
a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter, with the additions,
insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section
10-1-3 of this chapter.
(Ord. 2016-04, passed 4-12-2016)
§ 10-1-2 INCONSISTENT ORDINANCES REPEALED.
   All other ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby
repealed, except the 1978 zoning ordinance, 1978 subdivision regulations, and
the amendments thereto.
§ 10-1-3 AMENDMENTS TO CODE.
   The following sections are hereby revised to insert the following in the
appropriate part thereof:
   Section 101.1 Insert: City of Chandler, Oklahoma
   Section 1612.3 Insert: City of Chandler, Oklahoma
   Section 1612.3 Insert: July 16, 1996
(Ord. 2016-04, passed 4-12-2016)
§ 10-1-4 FIRE LIMITS.
   The City Council may hereinafter establish such fire limits as it deems
appropriate and necessary for the proper enforcement and application of this
chapter.
§ 10-1-5 BUILDING PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION; ISSUANCE.
   (A)   Permit Required. No building or other structure shall be built,
enlarged, altered or moved without a permit from the building official
therefor, as provided in the City’s Building Code.
   (B)   Application for Permit. Application for building permits (including
permits for moving buildings) shall be made to the building official. The
applicant shall provide such plans, specifications and other data as may be
necessary for the building official to determine whether the permit shall be
issued. Posting of addresses is required.
   (C)   Fees. Fees for building permits shall be set by the City Council by
motion or resolution.
§ 10-1-6 SMOKE DETECTORS.
   Effective January 1, 1980, the Building Code of the City is hereby amended
and supplemented to require the installation of a smoke detector in any new
residential building, unoccupied storage area of any new business building
constructed within the City. The detector herein required, shall be one
approved, listed and labeled by the Building Code, as meeting requirements for
detection of invisible and visible particles of combustion and must be
installed in a manner and location consistent with this listing, and when
activated the detector must provide an alarm suitable to warn occupants within
the building.
§ 10-1-7 SWIMMING POOL FENCE ENCLOSURES.
   (A)   Fence Enclosure Required. All outdoor swimming pools shall be
completely enclosed by metal, wood or masonry fencing of not less than forty-
two inches (42") in height with no opening greater than four inches (4") in
width, except for gateways and doorways.
   (B)   Wall as Portion of Fence. Any wall or portion of a single-family
residence may constitute a portion or all of the above required enclosure.
However, no part of any apartment, motel or other dwelling structure shall form
a portion of the required enclosure unless there is no door or access from such
structure forming a part of the enclosure.
   (C)   Fence Maintenance. All fences enclosing swimming pools shall be
maintained in a secure, safe and operating condition at all times.
   (D)   Self-Closing Gate and Latch. Any gate or opening into an outdoor pool
enclosure shall be equipped with self-closing and self-latching devices and
shall be closed and secured at all times, except that a doorway of a single-
family residence need not be so equipped.
§ 10-1-8 EXISTING BUILDING CODE ADOPTED.
   (A)   A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the
Office of the City Clerk of the City of Chandler, Oklahoma, being marked and
designated as the International Existing Building Code, 2015 edition, including
all appendix chapters as published by the International Code Council, be and is
hereby adopted as the Existing Building Code of the City of Chandler, Oklahoma
for regulating and governing the repair, alteration, change of occupancy,
addition, and relocation of existing buildings, including historic buildings,
as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of
fees therefor, and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties,
conditions and terms of said Existing Building Code on file in the Office of
the Chandler City Clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part
hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with the additions, insertions,
deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection (B) of this section.
   (B)   The following sections are hereby revised to insert the following in
the appropriate part thereof:
      Section 101.1 Insert: City of Chandler, Oklahoma
      Section 1401.2 Insert: January 3, 1980
(Ord. 2016-02, passed 4-12-2016)

   Section 305.4.1 Insert in both locations: Not less than 18 inches
   Section 904.1 Insert: 6" (152 mm)
(Ord. 2016-05, passed 4-12-2016)
§ 10-2-4 CERTIFICATES OF REGISTRATION.
   (A)   Registration of Plumbers.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business,
trade, or occupation of a plumbing contractor, journeyman plumber, or plumbing
apprentice, by advertisement or otherwise, in the City, unless that person is
registered with the City and has purchased a current and valid certificate of
registration issued by the City.
      (2)   A contractor certificate of registration shall be issued only to
those who have a valid Oklahoma State Department of Health contractor license.
Each firm shall have a contractor employed full time who is responsible for
planning, contracting, supervising, or furnishing of labor and/or materials
used in the trade. A contractor may not have more than three (3) apprentices
under direct “on the job” supervision.
      (3)   A journeyman certificate of registration shall be issued only to
those who have a valid Oklahoma State Department of Health journeyman license.
A journeyman may not have more than three (3) apprentices under direct “on the
job” supervision.
      (4)   An apprentice certificate of registration shall be issued only to
those who have a valid Oklahoma state department of health apprentice license.
An apprentice shall be under the direct “on the job” supervision of a licensed
and registered journeyman or contractor.
      (5)   Each person registered as a contractor, journeyman or apprentice
shall have such certificate of registration on his/her person while engaging in
the work of a contractor, journeyman or apprentice.
      (6)   Certificates of registration are nontransferable.
      (7)   The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to property
owners working on his/her owner occupied single-family residence.
   (B)   Expiration and Renewal; Fees.
      (1)   Upon application to the city, the city shall register such
applicants and issue them certificates of registration in the applicable
category, after the applicant has complied with the laws of the state,
ordinances of the city, and paid the applicable fees set by the city council by
motion or resolution.
      (2)   The registration shall expire on June 30 of each year. Persons
desiring to renew their registration shall furnish the same evidence of
compliance with state law and city ordinance and pay the applicable fees set by
council by motion or resolution.
   (C)   Revocation of Registration; Hearing.
      (1)   The city council, upon at least ten (10) days’ notice and adequate
opportunity for a public hearing, may suspend or revoke the certificate of
registration of any contractor, journeyman or apprentice for violating any
provision of any ordinance or regulation relating to the installation of
plumbing materials or fixtures or registration of personnel.
      (2)   A request for a public hearing may be presented to council by the
code official or any aggrieved person.
(Ord. 1997-09, passed 10-7-1997)
§ 10-2-5 PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Compliance with Adopted Code. Permits are required in accordance with
Section 106 of the International Plumbing Code.
   (B)   Application for Permit. Applications for permits shall be delivered to
city hall, 414 Manvel, and the applicant shall provide such plans,
specifications and any additional information as may be designated by the code
official.
   (C)   Fee. Upon approval of the application by the city, the applicant shall
pay the permit fee as set by city council by motion or resolution.
   (D)   Contractor Responsibility. It shall be the responsibility of the
plumbing contractor to obtain any required permits.
(Ord. 1997-09, passed 10-7-1997)
§ 10-2-6 PLUMBING INSPECTOR; INSPECTION OF WORK.
   (A)   Plumbing Inspector; Office Created, Powers and Duties.
      (1)   There shall be a plumbing inspector who shall be the code official.
The inspector shall have the powers and duties in accordance with Sections 103
and 104 of the International Plumbing Code.
      (2)   The plumbing inspector shall have the authority to make special
rulings, when circumstances warrant, for the safeguarding of life or property.
The plumbing contractor and the property owner will be notified in writing of
special rulings.
      (3)   It is the authority of the plumbing inspector to inspect all
plumbing materials and fixtures for which a permit has been issued.
      (4)   The plumbing inspector shall have the right of entry as described
in Section 104.5 of the International Plumbing Code. Any person interfering
with the plumbing inspector shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a
fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code.
   (B)   Inspection of Work.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or
individual to conceal or cause to be concealed any work for which a permit is
required, until it is known by that person that the installation has been
approved by the city. Additionally, inspections are required in accordance with
Section 107 of the International Plumbing Code.
      (2)   It shall be the responsibility of the contractor to request all
inspections. Such request shall be made at least twenty-four (24) hours prior
to the desired inspection time.
(Ord. 1997-09, passed 10-7-1997)
§ 10-2-7 NONLIABILITY OF CITY FOR DAMAGES.
   The provisions of this chapter are not intended, nor shall they be
construed, so as to create liability or responsibility to any person, firm or
corporation on the part of any officer, employee or agent of the city or the
city itself by reason of the inspection of plumbing facilities nor the approval
or disapproval thereof.
(Ord. 1997-09, passed 10-7-1997)
§ 10-2-8 WATER AND SEWER CONNECTIONS.
   It shall be unlawful for any individual to connect or cause to be connected
to a city water or sewer main, unless authorized by the city to do so.
(Ord. 1997-09, passed 10-7-1997)
§ 10-2-9 PENALTY.
   Any person who shall violate a provision of the International Plumbing Code
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and subject to a fine as provided for in
section 1-4-1 of this code. Each day that a violation continues after due
notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 1997-09, passed 10-7-1997)

the Chandler city clerk, being marked and designated as the ICC Electrical Code
- Administrative Provisions, 2003 edition, as published by the International
Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the electrical code of the city of
Chandler, for regulating the design, construction, quality of materials,
erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement,
addition to, use or maintenance of electrical systems as herein provided;
providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each
and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said

referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out herein, with
the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section
10-3-3 of this chapter.

   Section 101.1. Insert: city of Chandler, Oklahoma
   Section 404.2. Insert: city fee schedule, chapter 10, title 1 of the
Chandler city code
(Ord. 2004-15, passed 12-7-2004)
§ 10-3-4 CERTIFICATES OF REGISTRATION.
   (A)   Registration of Electricians.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business,
trade, or occupation of an electrical contractor, journeyman electrician, or
electrical apprentice, by advertisement or otherwise, in the city unless he is
registered with the city and has purchased a current and valid certificate of
registration issued by the city.
      (2)   A contractor certificate of registration shall be issued only to
those who have a valid Oklahoma state department of health contractor license.
Each firm shall have a contractor employed full time who is responsible for the
planning, contracting, supervising, or furnishing of labor and/or materials
used in the trade. A contractor may have no more than two (2) apprentices under
direct “on the job” supervision.
      (3)   A journeyman certificate of registration shall be issued only to
those who have a valid Oklahoma state department of health journeyman license.
A journeyman may not have more than two (2) apprentices under direct “on the
job” supervision.
      (4)   An apprentice certificate of registration shall be issued only to
those who have a valid Oklahoma state department of health apprentice license.
An apprentice shall be under the direct “on the job” supervision of a licensed
and registered journeyman or contractor.
      (5)   Each person registered as a contractor, journeyman or apprentice
shall have such certificate of registration on his/her person while engaging in
the work of a contractor, journeyman or apprentice.
      (6)   Certificates of registration are nontransferable.
      (7)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
         (a)   Minor repairs consisting of repairing or replacing outlets or
minor working parts of electrical fixtures.
         (b)   Maintenance work for state and federal institutions.
         (c)   The construction, installation, maintenance, repair and
renovation of telephone equipment or computer systems used for the
communication of voice or data.
         (d)   Property owners working on his/her owner occupied single-family
dwelling.
   (B)   Expiration and Renewal; Fees.
      (1)   Upon application to the city, the city shall register such
applicants and issue them certificates of registration in the applicable
category, after the applicant has complied with the laws of the state,
ordinances of the city and paid the applicable fees set by the city council by
motion or resolution.
      (2)   The registration shall expire on June 30 of each year. Persons
desiring to renew their registration shall furnish the same evidence of
compliance with state law and city ordinance and pay the applicable fees set by
the city council by motion or resolution.
   (C)   Revocation of Registration; Hearing.
      (1)   The city council, upon at least ten (10) days’ notice and adequate
opportunity for a public hearing, may suspend or revoke the certificate of
registration of any contractor, journeyman or apprentice for violating any
provision of any ordinance or regulation relating to the installation of
electrical equipment or registration of personnel.
      (2)   A request for a public hearing may be presented to the city council
by the code official or any aggrieved person.
(Ord. 1993-03, passed 9-7-1993)
§ 10-3-5 PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Permit Required. Electrical permits are required for any person to
install a new circuit, expand an existing circuit by three (3) or more devices,
or the addition, alteration or changing of a breaker box or fuse box exceeding
sixty (60) amperes. Such permits are required prior to beginning said work.
   (B)   Application for Permit. Applications for permits shall be made to the
city, and the applicant shall provide such plans, specifications and other data
as may be required by the code official.
   (C)   Fee. Upon approval of the application by the city, the applicant shall
pay the permit fee as set by the city council by motion or resolution.
   (D)   Contractor Responsibility. It shall be the responsibility of the
electrical contractor to obtain any required permits.
(Ord. 1993-03, passed 9-7-1993)
§ 10-3-6 ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR; INSPECTION OF WORK.
   (A)   Electrical Inspector; Office Created, Powers and Duties.
      (1)   There shall be an electrical inspector who shall be the code
official.
      (2)   The electrical inspector shall have the authority to make special
rulings, when circumstances warrant, for the safeguarding of life or property.
The electrical contractor and the property owner will be notified in writing of
special rulings.
      (3)   It is the authority of the electrical inspector to inspect all
electrical equipment for which a permit has been issued.
      (4)   The electrical inspector shall have the power to make an annual
inspection of all electrical equipment in commercial and public buildings in
the city. When any electrical installations are found to be in an unsafe or
hazardous condition, the electrical inspector shall notify the property owner
such electrical conditions exist, and advise the property owner to take
corrective action by placing electrical equipment in a safe condition. Any
person, firm or corporation failing or refusing to make correction of hazardous
or unsafe electrical installations, after having been notified by the
electrical inspector, shall be fined according to the provisions of this
chapter. Each day after the expiration of the time designated to make
corrections shall constitute a separate offense. When hazardous or unsafe
electrical conditions exist and any person, firm or corporation fails to make
corrections after having been notified, the electrical inspector shall have the
authority to order the utility company to discontinue the electric service.
      (5)   The electrical inspector, while in the discharge of his official
duty, shall have the authority to enter any building or premises at any
reasonable hour, for the purpose of making any electrical inspection,
reinspection, or test of the electrical equipment contained therein or its
installation; and any person interfering with the electrical inspector shall be
fined as provided for in this chapter; provided however, the inspector shall
not enter private residences not then under renovation without first obtaining
permission from an occupant thereof.
   (B)   Inspection of Work.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or
individual to conceal or cause to be concealed any work for which a permit is
required, until it is known by that person that the installation has been
approved by the city.
      (2)   It shall be the responsibility of the contractor to request all
required inspections. Such request shall be made at least twenty-four (24)
hours prior to the desired inspection time.
      (3)   New work “roughed in” shall include all electrical equipment to
make the installation complete, be free from unintentional grounds, with joints
properly made up, ready for the attachment of fixtures, drop lights and
appliances.
(Ord. 1993-03, passed 9-7-1993)
§ 10-3-7 NONLIABILITY OF CITY FOR DAMAGES.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed to affect the
responsibility or liability of any party owning, operating, controlling, or
installing any electrical equipment for damages to persons or to property
caused by any defect therein, nor shall the city or any officer or employee of
the city, be held as assuming such liability by reason of the inspection or
reinspection as herein provided or by reason of the approval or disapproval of
any equipment authorized herein.
(Ord. 1993-03, passed 9-7-1993)
§ 10-3-8 ELECTRIC SERVICE CONNECTION.
   It is unlawful for any public service corporation, any individual, any
light, heat, or power company to connect, or cause to be connected, any service
or building, for the supply of electric current for light, heat or power, until
they have been notified by the electrical inspector that the electrical work
has been inspected and is ready for electric service.
(Ord. 1993-03, passed 9-7-1993)
§ 10-3-9 PENALTY.
   Any person who shall violate a provision of the National Electrical Code
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and subject to a fine as provided for in
section 1-4-1 of this code. Each day that a violation continues after due
notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 1993-03, passed 9-7-1993)
CHAPTER 4: MECHANICAL CODE
Section
   
10-4-1   Mechanical Code Adopted
   
10-4-2   Inconsistent Ordinances Repealed
   
10-4-3   Amendments to Code

§ 10-4-1 MECHANICAL CODE ADOPTED.

the City Clerk of the City of Chandler, Oklahoma, being marked and designated
as the International Mechanical Code, 2015 edition, including all appendix
chapters as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby
adopted as the Mechanical Code of the City of Chandler, Oklahoma for regulating
and governing the design, construction, quality of materials, erection,
installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition
to, use or maintenance of mechanical systems as provided herein; providing for
the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of
the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Mechanical
Code on file in the Office of the Chandler City Clerk are hereby referred to,
adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter, with the
additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 10-
4-3 of this chapter.
(Ord. 2016-01, passed 4-12-2016)

Section 4-1 of the Chandler City Code
   Section 108.5 Insert: $100/$500
(Ord. 2016-01, passed 4-12-2016)
§ 10-4-4 CERTIFICATES OF REGISTRATION.
   (A)   Registration of Mechanical Workers.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business,
trade, or occupation of a mechanical contractor, mechanical journeyman, or
mechanical apprentice, by advertisement or otherwise, in the City unless that
person is registered with the City and has purchased a current and valid
certificate of registration issued by the City.
      (2)   A contractor certificate of registration shall be issued only to
those who have a valid Oklahoma State Department of Health contractor license.
Each firm shall have a contractor employed full time who is responsible for the
planning, contracting, supervising, or furnishing of labor and of materials
used in the trade. A contractor may not have more than three (3) apprentices
under direct “on the job” supervision.
      (3)   A journeyman certificate of registration shall be issued only to
those who have a valid Oklahoma State Department of Health journeyman license.
A journeyman may not have more than three (3) apprentices under direct “on the
job” supervision.
      (4)   An apprentice certificate of registration shall be issued only to
those who have a valid Oklahoma State Department of Health apprentice license.
An apprentice shall be under the direct “on the job” supervision of a licensed
and registered journeyman or contractor.
      (5)   Each person registered as a contractor, journeyman or apprentice
shall have such certificate of registration on his/her person while engaging in
the work of a contractor, journeyman or apprentice.
      (6)   Certificates of registration are nontransferable.
      (7)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to property owners
working on his/her owner occupied single-family residence.
      (8)   Each contractor or journeyman certificate of registration shall be
issued in one or more of the following categories:
         (a)   Limited air conditioning: Entitles the certificate holder to
work with equipment that has a cooling capacity of not more than twenty-five
(25) tons or three hundred thousand (300,000) BTU.
         (b)   Unlimited air conditioning: Entitles the certificate holder to
work with equipment of any capacity.
         (c)   Limited heating: Entitles the certificate holder to work with
equipment that has a heat input of not more than five hundred thousand
(500,000) BTU or 143.5 kilowatts or a water temperature of not more than two
hundred ten degrees Fahrenheit (210°F).
         (d)   Unlimited heating: Entitles the certificate holder to work with
equipment of any capacity.
         (e)   Natural gas piping: Entitles the certificate holder to work with
natural gas piping.
         (f)   Process piping: Entitles the certificate holder to work with
process piping.
         (g)   Refrigeration: Entitles the certificate holder to work with
refrigeration systems, including process piping.
         (h)   Sheet metal: Entitles the certificate holder to work with sheet
metal systems.
   (B)   Expiration and Renewal; Fees.
      (1)   Upon application to the city, the city shall register such
applicants and issue the appropriate type of certificate of registration, after
the applicant has complied with the laws of the state, ordinances of the city,
and paid the applicable fees set by the city council by motion or resolution.
      (2)   The registration shall expire on June 30 of each year. Persons
desiring to renew their registration shall furnish the same evidence of
compliance with state law and city ordinance and pay the applicable fees set by
council by motion or resolution.
   (C)   Revocation of Registration; Hearing.
      (1)   The city council, upon at least ten (10) days’ notice and adequate
opportunity for a public hearing, may suspend or revoke the certificate of
registration of any contractor, journeyman or apprentice for violating any
provision of any ordinance or regulation relating to the installation,
maintenance or repair of mechanical equipment or registration of personnel.
      (2)   A request for a public hearing may be presented to the city council
by the code official or any aggrieved person.
(Ord. 1997-10, passed 10-7-1997)
§ 10-4-5 PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Permit Required. Permits are required in accordance with Section 106
of the International Plumbing Code.
   (B)   Application for Permit. Applications for permits shall be delivered to
city hall, 414 Manvel, and the applicant shall provide such plans,
specifications and any additional information as may be designated by the code
official.
   (C)   Fee. Upon approval of the application by the city, the applicant shall
pay the permit fee as set by the city council by motion or resolution.
   (D)   Contractor Responsibility. It shall be the responsibility of the
mechanical contractor to obtain any required permits.
(Ord. 1997-10, passed 10-7-1997)
§ 10-4-6 MECHANICAL INSPECTOR; INSPECTION OF WORK.
   (A)   Mechanical Inspector; Office Created, Powers and Duties.
      (1)   There shall be a mechanical inspector who shall be the code
official. The inspector shall have the powers and duties in accordance with
Sections 103 and 104 of the International Mechanical Code.
      (2)   The mechanical inspector shall have the authority to make special
rulings when the circumstances warrant, for the safeguarding of life or
property. The mechanical contractor and the property owner will be notified in
writing of special rulings.
      (3)   It is the authority of the mechanical inspector to inspect all
mechanical materials and equipment for which a permit has been issued.
      (4)   The mechanical inspector shall have the right of entry as described
in Section 104.5 of the International Mechanical Code. Any person interfering
with the mechanical inspector shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a
fine as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code.
   (B)   Inspection of Work.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or
individual to conceal any work for which a permit is required, until it is
known by that person that the work has been approved by the city. Inspections
are required in accordance with Section 107 of the International Mechanical
Code.
      (2)   It shall be the responsibility of the mechanical contractor to
request all mechanical inspections. Such requests shall be made at least
twenty-four (24) hours prior to the desired inspection time.
(Ord. 1997-10, passed 10-7-1997)
§ 10-4-7 NONLIABILITY OF CITY FOR DAMAGES.
   The provisions of this chapter are not intended, nor shall they be
construed, so as to create liability or responsibility to any person, firm or
corporation on the part of any officer, employee or agent of the city or the
city itself by reason of the inspection of mechanical facilities nor the
approval or disapproval thereof.
(Ord. 1997-10, passed 10-7-1997)
§ 10-4-8 SERVICE CONNECTION.
   It shall be unlawful for any individual or company to connect or cause to be
connected any service until they have been notified by the inspector that such
work has been inspected and approved.
(Ord. 1997-10, passed 10-7-1997)
§ 10-4-9 PENALTY.
   Any person who shall violate a provision of the International Mechanical
Code shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and subject to a fine as provided for in
section 1-4-1 of this code. Each day that a violation continues after due
notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 1997-10, passed 10-7-1997)

§ 10-6-1 FIRE CODE ADOPTED.

Office of the City Clerk of the City of Chandler, Oklahoma, being marked and
designated as the International Fire Code, 2015 edition, including all appendix
chapters as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby
adopted as the Fire Code of the City of Chandler, Oklahoma regulating and
governing the safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards
arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials
and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy
of buildings and premises as provided herein; providing for the issuance of
permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations,
provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Fire Code on file in the
Office of the Chandler City Clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a
part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter, with the additions,
insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection (B) of this
chapter.
   (B)   The following sections are hereby revised to insert the following in
the appropriate part thereof:
      Section 101.1 Insert: City of Chandler, Oklahoma
      Section 109.3 Insert: Misdemeanor punishable as set forth in Title 1,
Section 4-1 of the Chandler City Code
      Section 111.4 Insert: $100 to $500
   (C)   The geographic limits referred to in certain sections of the 2015
International Fire Code are hereby established as follows: All such
jurisdictional limits shall be as set forth in the Zoning Code for the City of
Chandler, Oklahoma.
(Ord. 2016-03, passed 4-12-2016)
§ 10-6-2 MODIFICATIONS.
   (A)   Authority. The Chief of the Fire Department, with the approval of the
City Council, shall have power to modify any of the provisions of the Fire Code
upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly authorized
agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the
strict letter of the Fire Code; provided, that the spirit of the Fire Code
shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial justice done.
   (B)   Record Kept of Modifications. The particulars of such modification
when granted or allowed and the decision of the Fire Chief and City Council
thereon shall be entered upon the records of the Council, and a signed copy
shall be furnished the applicant.
(Ord. 2016-03, passed 4-12-2016)
§ 10-6-3 ENFORCEMENT BY FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   Authority; Definitions.
      (1)   The Fire Code shall be enforced by the Fire Department of the City,
under the supervision of the Chief of the Fire Department.
      (2)   The Chief of the Fire Department may detail such members of the
Fire Department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. The City
may appoint such inspectors as the City Council may authorize.
      (3)   The terms BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION and CHIEF OF THE BUREAU OF FIRE
PREVENTION, wherever found in the Fire Code, shall mean Fire Department and
Chief of the Fire Department, respectively, of the City. Whenever the word
MUNICIPALITY is used in the Fire Code, it means the City of Chandler.
   (B)   Inspectors. The Chief of the Fire Department may detail such members
of the Fire Department as inspectors as may from time to time be necessary.
(Ord. 2016-03, passed 4-12-2016)
§ 10-6-4 STORAGE LIMITS FOR FLAMMABLES AND EXPLOSIVES.
   (A)   Flammable Liquids.
      (1)   The limits referred to in section 16.22 of the Fire Code, in which
storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited, are
hereby established as the City limits, but this provision shall not apply to
such tanks already in existence as of May 1, 1983.
      (2)   The limits referred to in section 16.51 of the Fire Code, in which
new bulk plants for flammable liquids are prohibited, are hereby established as
the City limits, but this provision shall not apply to plants already in
existence as of May 1, 1983.
   (B)   Liquefied Petroleum Gases. The limits referred to in section 21.6a of
the Fire Code, in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum has been
prohibited, are hereby established as the City limits, but this provision shall
not apply to storage already in existence as of May 1, 1983.
   (C)   Explosives and Blasting Agents. The limits referred to in the Fire
Code, in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited, are
hereby established as the City limits, except as provided in the City’s zoning
regulations.
(Ord. 2016-03, passed 4-12-2016)
§ 10-6-5 NEW MATERIALS, PROCESSES OR OCCUPANCIES; PERMITS.
   The Chief of the Fire Department and two (2) persons appointed by the Mayor,
with the approval of the City Council, shall act as a committee to determine
and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new
materials, processes, or occupancies, which shall require permits, in addition
to those now enumerated in said code. The Fire Chief shall post such list in a
conspicuous place in his office, and distribute copies thereof to interested
persons.
§ 10-6-6 APPEALS.
   Whenever the Chief of the Fire Department shall disapprove an application or
refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions
of the Fire Code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code
have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from
the decision of the Chief of the Fire Department to the City Council within
thirty (30) days from the date of the decision.
(Ord. 2016-03, passed 4-12-2016)
§ 10-6-7 PENALTIES.
   (A)   Penalty Imposed.
      (1)   Any person who violates any of the provisions of the Fire Code
hereby adopted or fails to comply therewith, or who violates or fails to comply
with any order made thereunder, or who builds in violation of any detailed
statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any
certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been
taken, or who fails to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the
City Council or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed
therein, shall severally for every such violation and noncompliance
respectively, be guilty of an offense, punishable by a fine as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this Code.
      (2)   The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse
the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required
to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time. When
not otherwise specified, each ten (10) days that prohibited conditions are
maintained shall constitute a separate offense.
   (B)   Removal of Prohibited Conditions. The application of the above penalty
shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions.
(Ord. 2016-03, passed 4-12-2016)

§ 10-8-1 ENERGY CONSERVATION CODE ADOPTED.
   A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of
the Chandler city clerk being marked and designated as the International Energy

(Ord. 2004-14, passed 11-2-2004)
§ 10-8-2 AMENDMENTS TO CODE.
   The following sections are hereby revised to insert the following in the
appropriate part thereof:
   Section 101.1. Insert: city of Chandler, Oklahoma
(Ord. 2004-14, passed 11-2-2004)
§ 10-8-3 GENERAL STANDARDS.
   (A)   One- and Two-Family Dwellings. This standard establishes structural,
mechanical and plumbing criteria which are acceptable as minimum energy
conservation requirements for one- and two-family dwellings constructed in the
city. Compliance with criteria established in this standard is recognized as
full compliance with energy conservation standards of the city insofar as one-
and two-family dwellings are concerned.
   (B)   Minimum Construction Requirements. This standard provides minimum
construction requirements without further submission of detailed plans,
specifications and/or engineering calculations.
   (C)   Engineering Data. If all of the mandatory criteria outlined in this
standard are not met, it will be necessary to submit engineering data as
required by the several construction codes of the city.
§ 10-8-4 MANDATORY STRUCTURAL REQUIREMENTS.
   The following requirements apply:
   (A)   Ceilings. Minimum R-19. Approved batt or blown insulation may be used
to achieve the R-19 requirement.
   (B)   Outside Walls. Minimum R-11. This can be achieved by use of one or
more approved materials.
   (C)   Floors (Wood Over Unheated Spaces). R-9. Insulation to be held in
place as recommended by manufacturer.
   (D)   Foundation and Slab Insulation. R-5.5.
      (1)   This insulation shall extend downward from the top of the slab for
a distance of twenty-four inches (24"); if the stem wall is less than twenty-
four inches (24"), the difference is to be turned in at footing;
      (2)   The insulation may be installed downward to the bottom of the slab
then horizontally beneath the slab for a total minimum distance of twenty-four
inches (24"); or
      (3)   In the case of a monolithic slab foundation, the insulation may be
used on outside of the wall from the top of a slab downward to the footing.
   (E)   Windows. Windows shall not exceed fifteen percent (15%) of the floor
area when single glazed. If larger area of glass is desired, double or triple
glazing must be utilized.
   (F)   Air Infiltration Reduction. Major areas of concern are exterior joints
between wall and foundation, and between wall cavities and window or door
frames. Exterior joints around windows and doors, between wall and roof,
between wall panels at penetrations or utility service through walls, and all
other openings in the exterior envelope shall be caulked, weather stripped, or
otherwise sealed. Vapor barriers are to be installed on heated side of the
envelope. Avoid double vapor barrier.
   (G)   Display of Card. A card signed by the contractor who installs any
insulation material is to be securely affixed to the structure adjacent to the
attic access. The card will display the following information:
      (1)   Name of installing contractor;
      (2)   Trade name of insulation(s);
      (3)   R factor for walls, ceiling, floor and/or slab; and
      (4)   Date of installation.
§ 10-8-5 MANDATORY MECHANICAL AND PLUMBING REQUIREMENTS.
   Compliance with the applicable energy conservation provisions of the city’s
adopted mechanical and plumbing codes will be enforced. Some specific examples
are listed below. Equipment should show necessary data on nameplate or attached
information sheets:
   (A)   Combustion Heating Equipment. All gas and oil fired comfort heating
equipment shall show a minimum combustion efficiency of seventy-five percent
(75%) at maximum rated output.
   (B)   Heat Pumps. Heat pumps when used for heating should have the following
minimum coefficient of performance (COP):
 
Source and Outdoor Temperature     Minimum COP
Air source 47 dry bulb/43 wet bulb 2.2
Air source 17 dry bulb/15 wet bulb 1.2
Water source 60 entering water     2.2
 
   (C)   Energy Efficiency Ratio. Minimum energy efficiency ratio (EER) and
coefficient of performance (COP) for electrically driven heating, ventilating
and air conditioning systems equipment when used for cooling:
 
Standard Rating Capacity             EER COP
Under 65,000 BTU/hour (19,050 watts) 6.1 6.8
65,000 BTU/hour and over             6.8 2.0
 
   (D)   Temperature Controls. Each heating system shall have at least one
adjustable thermostat for temperature regulation. Each thermostat shall be
capable of being set as follows:
      (1)   Where used to control heating only, a maximum setting of seventy-
five degrees Fahrenheit (75°F);
      (2)   Where used to control cooling only, a minimum setting of seventy
degrees Fahrenheit (70°F); and
      (3)   Where used to control both heating and cooling, the thermostat
shall have a maximum heating mode temperature setting of seventy-five degrees
Fahrenheit (75°F) and a minimum cooling mode temperature setting of seventy
degrees Fahrenheit (70°F) and shall be capable of operating the system heating
and cooling in sequence. For more sophisticated systems, refer to the
provisions of the city’s adopted mechanical and plumbing codes.
   (E)   Air Handling Duct System Insulation. All ducts outside the conditioned
area must have a minimum of two inches (2") insulation with a vapor seal.
   (F)   Hot Water Heaters. All automatic electric storage water heaters shall
have a standby loss not exceeding four (4) watts/two feet (2') of tank surface
area.
   (G)   Automatic Storage Heaters. All gas and oil fired automatic storage
heaters shall have a recovery efficiency, Er, not less than seventy-five
percent (75%) and have a standby loss percentage, S, not exceeding S = 2.3 +
67/V, where V = rated volume in gallons.
   (H)   Hot Water Heaters, Label. At this time, labels on domestic hot water
heaters in most retail outlets do not contain the information required by the
energy conservation code. However, most of the automatic storage tank hot water
heaters exceed these requirements. The labels should bear the AGA approval for
gas heaters or UL approval for electric heaters. All hot water heaters must be
automatic.

CHAPTER 10: MOBILE HOMES; TRAVEL TRAILERS; MANUFACTURED HOMES; PARKS
Section
   
10-10-1   Citation
   
10-10-2   Definitions
   
10-10-3   Freestanding Mobile Homes or Travel Trailers; Location
   
10-10-4   Nonresidential Mobile Trailers
   
10-10-5   Manufactured or Modular Home Subdivisions
   
10-10-6   Penalty; Injunctive Relief
§ 10-10-1 CITATION.
   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the MOBILE HOME, TRAILER
PARK, MANUFACTURED OR MODULAR HOUSING RULES AND REGULATIONS of the city, and
addresses the following three (3) categories: mobile homes parks, trailer parks
(RV), and manufactured or modular home subdivisions.
§ 10-10-2 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BUILDING CODE. The BOCA Basic Building Code adopted in chapter 1 of this
title.
   CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER. The legally designated health authority of the
city or his authorized representative.
   DEPENDENT MOBILE HOME. A mobile home which does not have a flush toilet and
a bath or shower. For purposes of regulation under this chapter, a DEPENDENT
MOBILE HOME shall be considered to be the same as a dependent travel trailer,
unless otherwise specified.
   DEPENDENT TRAVEL TRAILER. A travel trailer which does not have a flush
toilet and a bath or shower.
   FIA or FEDERAL INSURANCE ADMINISTRATOR AND FLOOD HAZARD MAP. See definition
of “flood insurance rate map (FIRM)” in section 13-1-3 of this code.
   FREESTANDING MOBILE HOME OR TRAVEL TRAILER. Any mobile home or travel
trailer not located in a mobile home park or travel trailer park, respectively,
licensed by the city or in an approved mobile home subdivision.
   INDEPENDENT TRAVEL TRAILER. A travel trailer which has a flush toilet and a
bath or shower.
   MHI. Manufactured housing institute.
   MMH. Manufactured or modular housing.
   MANUFACTURED OR MODULAR HOME SUBDIVISION. A subdivision designed and
intended for residential use where residence is in manufactured or modular
homes exclusively and manufactured or modular home lots are sold for occupancy.
   MOBILE HOME. A structure, transportable in one or more sections, which is
built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used with or without a
permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities. It does not
include recreational vehicles or travel trailers. Compliance with the Chandler
subdivision regulations is required. For the purpose of this chapter, the terms
MOBILE HOME and MANUFACTURED HOUSING are interchangeable for units larger than
three hundred twenty (320) square feet of floor space.
   MOBILE HOME SPACE. A plot of ground within a mobile home park designed for
the accommodation of one mobile home and not located in a mobile home sales
lot.
   MOBILE OR MODULAR HOME PARK. Any plot of ground upon which two (2) or more
mobile homes, occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes, are located,
regardless of whether or not a charge is made for such accommodations.
   MODULAR HOME. A single, detached dwelling designed or used as long term
living quarters, which is transported, after off site fabrication, to a site
where it is ready for occupancy and permanently located. A MODULAR HOME does
not have a chassis with axles and wheels, but is normally hauled to the
permanent home site and shall be placed on a prepared foundation.
   NATIONAL MOBILE HOME CONSTRUCTION AND SAFETY STANDARDS ACT OF 1974, SECTION
604. Means 42 U.S.C. §§ 5401 et seq., and regulations of the UN-16 department
of housing and urban development.
   NONRESIDENTIAL MOBILE TRAILER. Any vehicle having the basic characteristics
of either a mobile home or travel trailer, but which is used for purposes other
than residential and is not being offered for sale (as indicated by a clearly
displayed sign on or near the trailer).
   PARK. A mobile home park and/or travel trailer park.
   PERSON. Natural individual, firm, trust, partnership, association or
corporation.
   PUBLIC WATER SYSTEM or PUBLIC SEWER SYSTEM. Any such system built and owned
by, or dedicated to and accepted by, the city. All other such systems are
private.
   SERVICE BUILDING. A building housing toilet and bathing facilities for men
and/or women, and may also include buildings containing laundry facilities as
required by this chapter or desired by the park operator.
   SUBDIVISION. Mobile home subdivision unless otherwise indicated.
   TRAVEL TRAILER. All vehicles and portable structures built on a chassis,
designed as a temporary or permanent dwelling for travel, recreational, and
vacation use, including tent trailers and motor driven vehicles, and
“independent travel trailers” and “dependent travel trailers” as defined in
this section.
   TRAVEL TRAILER PARK. Any plot of ground on which two (2) or more travel
trailers occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes are located.
   TRAVEL TRAILER SPACE. A plot of ground within a travel trailer park designed
for accommodation of one travel trailer.
§ 10-10-3 FREESTANDING MOBILE HOMES OR TRAVEL TRAILERS; LOCATION.
   (A)   Location Restricted. Except as hereinafter provided, no freestanding
mobile home or travel trailer shall be permitted in the city urban area unless
it is being offered for sale or parked for storage.
   (B)   Mobile Homes. Those freestanding mobile homes which are now
nonconforming uses under the provisions of the city zoning ordinance may
continue as nonconforming uses; provided, that they shall not be stored in
front yards or on side yards abutting a street on corner lots or on streets.
   (C)   Travel Trailers. No freestanding travel trailer shall be permitted in
the city urban area except in RV trailer parks or mobile home parks unless it
is being actively offered for sale or parked for storage; provided however,
that no travel trailer shall be stored in front yards or on side yards abutting
a street on corner lots or on streets, and further provided, that no water,
plumbing or permanent electrical connections shall be permitted.
   (D)   Offering for Sale; Storage.
      (1)   Except for mobile homes or travel trailers within regular
commercial RV or mobile home parks or sales lots or in other than an R-
1 residential district, each freestanding mobile home or travel trailer offered
for sale must be clearly marked as such, shall not be occupied for either
living or sleeping purposes and must be removed from the premises if not sold
within one hundred twenty (120) days.
      (2)   Freestanding mobile homes or travel trailers located within regular
commercial mobile home or travel trailer sales lots need be neither
individually marked for sale nor removed within one hundred twenty (120) days
if not sold.
      (3)   A property owner shall not store, nor permit to be stored, more
than one mobile home or travel trailer on a residential lot.
      (4)   The property owner shall not actively offer for sale more than one
mobile home in any twelve (12) month period.
      (5)   Such mobile home or travel trailer shall not be stored in any
required front yard or side yard or public utility easement, nor shall such
mobile home or travel trailer project beyond the front of any building.
   (E)   Freestanding Mobile Homes in Rural Areas.
      (1)   Freestanding mobile homes shall be permitted in the city rural area
but only so permitted in agricultural zoning districts as established by the
city zoning ordinance.
      (2)   Such freestanding mobile homes must comply with normal city
regulations, and the specific qualifications to the housing code outlined for
mobile homes in the minimum housing code of the city.
§ 10-10-4 NONRESIDENTIAL MOBILE TRAILERS.
   (A)   License Required.
      (1)   No nonresidential mobile trailer being used commercially shall be
permitted in the city unless a license for its operation is issued by the city.
Such license shall specify the permitted use of the nonresidential mobile
trailer, the location of such operation and the termination date of the permit.
      (2)   No license shall be issued for a use which would violate any city,
state or federal ordinance, law or regulation.
   (B)   License Fee. An annual fee as established by the city’s fee schedule
shall be charged for each nonresidential mobile trailer license, which shall
expire on April 30 each year, and be renewable on May 1 of each year
thereafter.
   (C)   Contractors on Construction Sites; Watchmen.
      (1)   Operation of nonresidential trailers by contractors on construction
projects for which building permits have been issued or which are otherwise
approved by government units is permitted during the term of such construction
project without issuance of a license.
      (2)   Operation of a nonresidential trailer for the explicit use of a
caretaker or night watchman on a permanent basis is permitted, provided all
other regulations of this chapter are complied with.
      (3)   An annual fee as established by the city’s fee schedule shall be
charged each such nonresidential mobile trailer license, which shall expire on
April 30 each year and be renewable on May 1 of each year thereafter.
   (D)   Permanent Location Prohibited. This chapter is not to be construed as
permitting or authorizing the permanent location of any nonresidential mobile
trailer in the city.
§ 10-10-5 MANUFACTURED OR MODULAR HOME SUBDIVISIONS.
   (A)   Compliance with Subdivision and Zoning Regulations.
      (1)   Manufactured and modular home subdivisions shall comply with the
subdivision and zoning ordinances of the city, except as otherwise provided.
      (2)   The minimum size of an MMH subdivision shall be five (5) acres.
      (3)   No residence except MMH shall be permitted in an MMH subdivision.
      (4)   Manufactured or modular housing subdivisions may be placed in any
area zoned AG-2, R-2, C-1, or HC with planning commission review and council
approval.
      (5)   Manufactured housing units shall meet HUD requirements and modular
housing units will meet city building code requirements.
      (6)   These units shall follow the housing and zoning requirements of the
city in regard to the setback, height, foundation, smoke alarms, sewer and
water connection.
   (B)   Effective Lot Widths.
      (1)   Minimum effective lot widths in an MMH subdivision shall be forty
feet (40') measured at the front building line, and minimum lot areas shall be
three thousand two hundred (3,200) square feet; provided, that at least five
foot (5') side yards measured from drip line shall be provided on each lot
beyond any MMH and additions thereto, except driveways.
      (2)   In areas not serviced by the public sewer, the minimum additional
lot area shall be determined by the code enforcement officer on the basis of
safe and sanitary sewer service.
      (3)   The effective lot width of an MMH lot shall be determined by
measuring at right angles across the lot from one parallel side line to the
other parallel side line.
      (4)   For cul-de-sac or odd shaped lots, the effective width shall be
determined by measuring at the building line parallel with the street from one
vertical side line to the other vertical side line that enclose the obtuse
angles. However, the front lot width shall be not less than twenty-five feet
(25').
   (C)   Side Line of Lots.
      (1)   Side line of lots in MMH subdivisions need not be at right angles
to straight street lines or radial to curved street lines.
      (2)   Regardless of the effective lot width, MMH subdivision lots must
abut a public street for at least twenty-five feet (25').
   (D)   Greenbelt Planting Strip.
      (1)   All MMH subdivisions shall provide suitable screening where
abutting single-family residential areas.
      (2)   A greenbelt area may be in the floodplain but may not be in a flood
hazard area.
   (E)   Floodplain and Flood Hazard Areas.
      (1)   No home site shall be in the flood hazard area.
      (2)   No home site shall be in the floodplain area without meeting all
federal insurance administration flood hazard regulations as adopted by the
city.
      (3)   A greenbelt area may be in the floodplain, but shall not be in the
flood hazard area (FIA map).
   (F)   Housing Units, Specific Requirements.
      (1)   All units must be permanently affixed to a foundation with a
legally identifiable portion of land owned in fee simple title and assume the
characteristics of residential property. To be permanently affixed to land,
each unit must be on a foundation permanently connected to water and sewer, set
up on the lot according to the manufacturer’s specifications, anchored to the
lot using certified anchors underpinned on all sides of the unit with a
compatible exterior covering material extending from the bottom of the unit to
the ground, and manufactured housing will have the wheels, axles and hitch
removed.
      (2)   All manufactured units must meet the federal mobile home
construction and safety standards (title VI, housing and community development
act of 1974) which became effective June 15, 1976. Modular housing must meet
the city’s building code.
      (3)   Exterior wall finish must be compatible to site built housing in
the local market. The finish will be real or simulated wood siding, stucco or a
combination of these finishes. The material may be metal or processed hardboard
such as masonite.
      (4)   There shall be a pitched roof (3 inches in 12 inches minimum) with
composition shingles.
      (5)   There shall be a ten inch (10") roof overhang.
      (6)   The minimum interior ceiling height shall be seven feet six inches
(7'6").
      (7)   The minimum unit size shall be seven hundred (700) square feet.
      (8)   Ten feet (10') shall be the minimum width.
      (9)   There shall be at least two (2) paved off street parking spaces as
required by the zoning ordinances.
      (10)   All units must meet zoning requirements for manufactured or
modular housing.
   (G)   City Permit Requirements. The city requires a building foundation
permit be applied for, including a listing of sizes, description and value of
the unit. Water tap fee, sewer tap fee, plumbing permits and electrical permits
are also required.
§ 10-10-6 PENALTY; INJUNCTIVE RELIEF.
   (A)   Penalty Imposed. Any person who shall engage in any business, trade or
vocation for which a license, permit, certificate or registration is required
by this chapter, without having a valid license, permit, certificate or
certificate of registration as required, or who shall fail to do anything
required by this chapter or by any code adopted by this chapter, or who shall
otherwise violate any provision of this chapter or of any code adopted by this
chapter, or who shall violate any lawful regulation or order made by any of the
officers provided for in this chapter, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be fined as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code.
   (B)   Relief in Courts. No penalty imposed by and pursuant to this chapter
shall interfere with the right of the city also to apply to the proper courts
of the state for a mandamus, an injunction or other appropriate action against
such person.
CHAPTER 11: OIL AND GAS WELLS
Section
   
10-11-1   Permits Required; Fees
   
10-11-2   Application for Permit
   
10-11-3   Supporting Documentation
   
10-11-4   Bond Requirement
   
10-11-5   Insurance Requirements
   
10-11-6   Justification for Refusal of Permit
   
10-11-7   Endangering Public Health
   
10-11-8   Preferential Permit Issuing
   
10-11-9   Operation of Well
   
10-11-10   Power Source for Pumping Units
   
10-11-11   Pollution Control
   
10-11-12   Chainlink Fence
   
10-11-13   Earthen Dikes
   
10-11-14   Revocation of Permit
   
10-11-15   Penalty
§ 10-11-1 PERMITS REQUIRED; FEES.
   (A)   Operation or Abandonment Permit. It is an offense for any person,
partnership, association or corporation to drill, operate, maintain, or abandon
any oil and/or gas well within the corporate limits of the city, or to work
upon or assist in any way in such work, unless a permit for such work is
authorized by the city council.
   (B)   Pipelines; Equipment. No pipeline, equipment, appliance or any
structure shall be laid, constructed, erected, maintained or permitted to
remain in, or under any street, alley, or public way without a special permit
in writing from the city council.
   (C)   Fees. Every applicant shall pay an application fee to the city and an
annual operating fee payable within thirty (30) days after each anniversary
date of the permit. Such fees shall be as established by the city’s fee
schedule.
§ 10-11-2 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   The permit required in section 10-11-1 of this chapter shall be issued only
to the owners of the oil and gas leasehold interest and every applicant for
such permit shall, at least ten (10) days prior to the proposed commencement of
such work, file a written application addressed to the city council for such
permit and such written application shall contain the following information:
   (A)   The name and address of each owner of an interest in the oil and gas
lease under which such well is to be drilled, operated, maintained or
abandoned;
   (B)   The name and address of the person or firm in charge of the operation
and maintenance of such well;
   (C)   The name and address of the person or firm in charge of the work to be
done under such permit;
   (D)   The exact location of the well or proposed well where the drilling or
other work is to be performed; and
   (E)   That the owners of the leasehold interest and persons in charge of the
drilling, operation, maintenance or abandonment of such well are familiar with
the ordinances of the city and will abide by the provisions thereof.
§ 10-11-3 SUPPORTING DOCUMENTATION.
   If the application is for a permit to drill a new well, the applicant shall
attach to his application exhibits reflecting the following:
   (A)   Exhibit A. Certificate by a bonded abstracter or an attorney at law
authorized to practice law in the state of Oklahoma, reflecting the names of
the owners of interest in the real estate situated within two hundred feet
(200') of such proposed well site;
   (B)   Exhibit B. A plat with detailed, scaled dimensions of the proposed
well location, lot and property lines within two hundred feet (200') of such
well site, with notation or reference thereon to the surface owner of all such
property as reflected by exhibit A;
   (C)   Exhibit C. A scale drawing of the proposed well site reflecting
proposed well location of drilling rig, motors, tanks and other principal
equipment to be used in the drilling of such well with reference being made to
property lines and structures (nature of structures being noted) located within
two hundred feet (200') of such well site; and
   (D)   Exhibit D. A scale drawing of proposed well site reflecting proposed
location of equipment, motors, tanks and other installations to be used in the
maintenance, operation and other work of such well with reference being made to
property lines and structures (nature of structures being noted) located within
two hundred feet (200') of such well site.
§ 10-11-4 BOND REQUIREMENT.
   (A)   Bond Required; Amount. Every applicant, at the time of filing its
application, shall also submit a bond in favor of the city in the amount as
established by the city’s fee schedule and executed by the applicant and a
corporate surety authorized to do business within the state and conditioned
that the applicant shall:
      (1)   Repair immediately any damage to paving, sidewalks, streets,
alleys, curbing, parking, sewers or other public property arising out of any
work relating to the well, all in accordance with the requirements of the city
and its authorized representative and under his supervision;
      (2)   Pay all fees and sums due the city hereunder and comply and abide
by the ordinances of the city and laws of the state; and
      (3)   The city council may increase or reduce the amount of such bond
required at or after the issuance of such permit.
   (B)   Lapse of Bond; Operation Suspended. In case any bond required herein
shall lapse or become void for any reason whatsoever, the permit issued under
the terms of this chapter shall immediately become inoperative and void until a
new bond shall be provided and filed with the city clerk or the existing bond
reinstated in full force, and such well shall be shut down and all operations
and production thereof suspended and discontinued until the filing of such new
bond or reinstatement of such existing bond.
§ 10-11-5 INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Insurance Required; Amounts. Each applicant shall also submit with its
written application a policy of public liability insurance, insuring the
applicant and the city against all claims or causes of action made against
either or both applicant and the city for damages to persons or property
arising out of the drilling, maintenance, operation or abandonment of such
well. The minimum amounts of such insurance shall be as established by the
city’s fee schedule.
   (B)   Notice to Applicant and City of Policy Change. Such insurance policy
shall contain a provision that the issuing company will not cancel or change
such policy of insurance except after thirty (30) days’ notice to the applicant
and the city.
§ 10-11-6 JUSTIFICATION FOR REFUSAL OF PERMIT.
   (A)   Location Near a Residence, Commercial Building, or Producing
Freshwater Well. No permit shall be granted for the drilling of a well or the
reentry into a plugged or abandoned well, if the well bore, or the exterior of
any tank batteries, pressure vessels, power stations, or other machinery,
facilities, or equipment of whatsoever nature is, or will be, located nearer
than four hundred feet (400') of any residence, commercial building, or
producing freshwater well. The four hundred feet (400') of separation from
residences and commercial buildings may be reduced to a distance of two hundred
feet (200') if written consent from all those having an interest in the surface
of the affected property within the reduced distance has been obtained and is
submitted with the drilling application. The four hundred feet (400') of
separation from a freshwater well may not be reduced. All distances specified
herein shall be measured from the production related item to the closest
exterior point of the residence, commercial building, or freshwater well.
   (B)   Location Near Another Well. No permit shall be granted for the
location of any vertical well within six hundred feet (600') of the location of
another well for which a permit had previously been granted. Subject to the
provisions of subsection (C) of this section, horizontally drilled wells may be
permitted in closer proximity than six hundred feet (600') if properly
authorized by state regulations and laws.
   (C)   Hazardous Conditions. The city council shall have the power and
reserves the authority to refuse any applicant for a permit where, by reason of
the location of the proposed well, its proximity to other wells, the character
and value of the permanent improvements in its vicinity, the use to which the
land and surroundings in proximity are adapted for civic or other purpose, or
for other reasons, the council considers such proposed well might constitute a
hazard to the public health, welfare and safety.
(Ord. 2005-12, passed 12-5-2005; Ord. 2007-05, passed 3-5-2007)
§ 10-11-7 ENDANGERING PUBLIC HEALTH.
   Every permit granted by the city shall be conditioned that whenever, in the
judgment of the city council, the public health, welfare and safety is
endangered or threatened by reason of the drilling, operation, maintenance or
abandonment of the well, the council may, if such condition is not corrected
within thirty (30) days after written notice thereof is given to permittee,
direct the owners and operators of the well to cease and desist in the further
work relating to the well and make any further order as such council may deem
proper and requisite in the premises in order to remove or avoid such threat or
hazard to the public health, safety and welfare, whether or not occasioned by
such operator or owners.
§ 10-11-8 PREFERENTIAL PERMIT ISSUING.
   In case there be applications filed with the city clerk and pending at the
same time, for permits to drill in any one drilling area of the city, by more
than one applicant, the application shall be granted, if otherwise sufficient,
which shall be made by the person, association or corporation holding the
greater area of the ground in the area, by lease or other contract with the
owners, permitting the drilling thereon for oil or gas.
§ 10-11-9 OPERATION OF WELL.
   (A)   Protection of Freshwater Strata. The well shall be cased and casing
cemented from the top of the well hole to a depth not less than fifty feet
(50') below all freshwater strata encountered in the well and in a manner that
will protect such freshwater from contamination resulting from the drilling or
operation of the well. Notwithstanding a compliance or attempted compliance
with the foregoing requirements of this section, if it is later determined that
a freshwater strata exists in the well which has not been properly cased and
cemented to the extent and in the manner necessary to protect such freshwater
strata from contamination, the permittee shall take such measures as may be
necessary to so protect the freshwater strata.
   (B)   Notify City. The permittee shall notify the city at least twenty-four
(24) hours prior to running the pipe for such work, for the purpose of
permitting the authorized representatives of the city to inspect such pipe on
the location, and, at least two (2) hours and not more than three (3) hours
before commencing the procedure to cement such pipe, the city shall be notified
thereof in order that a representative of the city may observe such procedure.
§ 10-11-10 POWER SOURCE FOR PUMPING UNITS.
   Electric power motors only shall be used for pumping units, unless approval
for use of other power is granted upon special application and permit of the
city council.
§ 10-11-11 POLLUTION CONTROL.
   The permittee shall take every reasonable precaution to prevent the escape
of noxious fumes, gases, oil or other substances from the location of such
well.
§ 10-11-12 CHAINLINK FENCE.
   All pumps, tanks and equipment used in the operation of a completed well
shall at a minimum, be enclosed on all sides by a chainlink fence six feet (6')
high with steel posts, with four (4) strands of barbed wire above such fence.
The council may require more stringent fencing in areas near city improvements
or areas developed for residential or commercial use. During drilling
operations, a watchman shall be maintained on the premises at all times who
shall be charged with the responsibility of protecting the general public from
any hazard resulting from the conduct of such drilling operations. If such
watchman is not employed, then the entire well location shall be fenced as in
the operation of a completed well. If the property at issue is later developed,
any application to plat the property shall constitute an agreement by the
developer to fence the well at developer’s expense as required by the city
council.
(Ord. 2005-03, passed 7-5-2005)
§ 10-11-13 EARTHEN DIKES.
   All tanks shall be surrounded by earthen dikes of sufficient height so as to
contain a capacity of fluid equal to one hundred fifty percent (150%) of the
capacity of such tanks. At well sites any portion of which are within three
hundred feet (300') of a city water supply, earthen dikes shall be constructed
surrounding all pumps, tanks and equipment of any nature to prevent, in the
city’s sole judgment, flooding thereof by said water supply.
(Ord. 2005-03, passed 7-5-2005)
§ 10-11-14 REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   In the event permittee should violate or fail to comply with any of the
provisions of this chapter or the order and direction of an authorized
representative of the city, acting pursuant to the authority granted herein,
the city council may cancel the permit or permits theretofore granted by the
city to the permittee, and the permittee shall cease and desist in any work
relating to any well, the permit for which has been canceled.
§ 10-11-15 PENALTY.
   It is an offense for any person, firm, association or corporation to
violate, or fail to comply with, any of the provisions of this chapter, and,
upon conviction thereof, such person, firm, association or corporation shall be
punished as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code.
CHAPTER 12: PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL CODE
Section
   
10-12-1   Private Sewage Disposal Code Adopted
   
10-12-2   Amendments to Code
§ 10-12-1 PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL CODE ADOPTED.
   A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of
the Chandler city clerk, being marked and designated as the International
Private Sewage Disposal Code, 2003 edition, including all appendix chapters, as
published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the
private sewage disposal code of the city of Chandler for regulating and
governing the design, construction, quality of materials, erection,
installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition
to, use or maintenance of individual sewage disposal systems as herein
provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees
therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties,
conditions and terms of said private sewage disposal code on file in the office
of the Chandler city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part
hereof, as if fully set out herein, with the additions, insertions, deletions
and changes, if any, prescribed in section
10-12-2 of this chapter.
(Ord. 2004-10, passed 11-2-2004)
§ 10-12-2 AMENDMENTS TO CODE.
   The following sections are hereby revised to insert the following in the
appropriate part thereof:
   Section 101.1. Insert: city of Chandler, Oklahoma
   Section 106.4.2. Insert: city fee schedule, chapter 10, title 1 of the
Chandler city code
   Section 106.4.3. Insert: subparagraph 2-75%. Delete subparagraph 3.
   Section 108.4. Insert: misdemeanor punishable as set forth in title 1,
section 4-1 of the Chandler city code.
   Section 108.5. Insert: $100/$500
   Section 405.2.5. Insert: date to be determined by the code enforcement
officer.
   Section 405.2.6. Insert: date to be determined by the code enforcement
officer.
(Ord. 2004-10, passed 11-2-2004)
